headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2009 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you ma
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2009 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker, our new Chief Operating Officer, announced in
componenttext: Thank you, good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Fourth Quarter and Year-End 2009 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker, our new Chief Operating Officer, announced in the press release yesterday evening; Andy Blocher; and Jeff Berkes. In addition to our fourth quarter and year-end 2009 supplemental disclosure package, we also filed our 10-K yesterday. Those documents provide you with significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust's 2009 operating and financial performance, and both are currently available on our website. Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Although Federal Realty believes expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained. Risks inherent in these assumptions include but are not limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of fourth quarter and year-end 2009 results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina and good morning, everybody. Well, 2009 is in the books and behind us. And despite what was undoubtedly the worst economic environment I have ever seen, I think that 2009 really was the year that Federal Realty business plan was validated as
componenttext: Thanks, Gina and good morning, everybody. Well, 2009 is in the books and behind us. And despite what was undoubtedly the worst economic environment I have ever seen, I think that 2009 really was the year that Federal Realty business plan was validated as a great long-term approach to owning real estate in a public structure. It's a plan built on three simple premises: Restricting investment to only top quality real estate; fiscal conservatism, both from a balance sheet and operating perspective; and balance as it relates to reliance on acquisitions, development and joint venture complexity.From a cash flow perspective, we generated more cash from operating activities in recession-plagued 2009, than ever before in our history, 13% more than 2008, which itself was 7% more than 2007. I'm talking about 2009 results and what they may foreshadow about 2010 in just a minute, but first, like to introduce the investor and analyst community to a partner of mine here at Federal for the last dozen years, and its new Chief Operating Officer, Dawn Becker. There hasn't been COO per se at Federal since I carried that title in 2001, and I couldn't be happier than to officially promote Dawn to that role, effective immediately, a role she's effectively been doing for the last 18 months. Our senior team has been together now for about 10 years, and 2009 certainly tested its strength and its resolve. Each of our team members wanted Dawn recognized with this promotion, I'm really proud of that. Some of you may know her or know of her, but Dawn will be coming to the Citigroup conference in Florida next month, and for the NAREIT Investor Conference in Chicago in June. So there'll certainly be opportunity to get to know her better in the months and the years ahead.Okay. let's talk about results and then our challenges and opportunities. FFO per share, excluding as we have all year, the litigation provision related to 350 Winchester Blvd. in San Jose, was $0.90 in the fourth quarter and $3.78 for the year, both down a bit from the comparable period last year when reported numbers were $0.99 and $3.85, respectively. The entire year-over-year decline in both the quarter and the year is directly attributable to proactive financing and liquidity management of the balance sheet in an uncertain environment. We basically borrowed and raised equity in excess of our needs earlier last year, just in case. And as the capital markets became more stable, we repaid some of it. Mildly earnings dilutive in the short term, conservative and balanced for the long term.On the leasing front, we continue to do just fine in terms deal volumes. You'll notice in the 8-K that we did 309 comparable deals for 1.2 million square feet in 2009, versus 300 deals for 1.2 million square feet in 2008, but with significantly tougher economics. Rollover rent growth was a strong 10% in 2009, but pales in comparison to the 21% rollover rent growth in 2008. That's a trend that we very much expect to continue in 2010. This playing out just as we thought it would, and have been talking about for some time now. At the macro level, there's simply too much retail space for the demand today and in the near future. And so both existing and new prospective tenants really value being in the best locations, but given the plethora of choices they have, the economic leverage is all theirs in most situations.The exceptions remain, where a particular tenant or group of tenants wants or needs a location really badly, and is willing to underwrite strong sales and profitability. In those cases, our rent growth will be strong as it will be in cases where an old expiring lease that was significantly under market can be re-leased in a much higher rent. In the fourth quarter, Priscilla of Boston will be opening a new store at Santana Row is one example, as are a couple of bank rents renewal in great locations in the Washington suburbs. But overall, on a portfolio-wide basis, it's clear that we're running into a headwind of conservatively underwritten tenant sales that's making them unwilling to stretch on rent.Now obviously, these dynamics are industry-wide and it follows that the better quality real estate to Federal loans will fair better. That has been the case and I see no reason as to why it won't continue to be. It's why we've not had significant challenges keeping occupancy at relatively strong levels even though rent growth has tailed off. Our portfolio was 94.5% leased and 93.2% occupied at the end of '09. Both numbers slightly better than they were at the end of the third quarter, which in turn were about the same as they were at the end of the second quarter. Occupancy is stable. So as I said on last quarter's call, I wouldn't rule out modest reductions stocking [ph] fee in 2010. But suffice it to say, we feel confident of our ability to manage occupancy to a reasonable level.I really believe, however, that one of the toughest challenges facing all retail real estate companies these days involves the balance inherent in the difficult day-to-day leasing decisions. There are plenty of deals to do out there, that's not the issue. But while executing long-term leases with poor economic terms that create a short-term pop in earnings may feel good now, but destruction in value to the entire shopping center that last for the next 10 or 20 years of the lease term, surely won't feel very good when times are better. I know we've had to make some of those decisions and it's no fun. The trick is coming up with the appropriate balance between the short-term pick up and the long-term pain. Those 2009 leasing dynamics led to modest same center growth 1% and 1.6% in the fourth quarter and for the full year of 2009, respectively, and all indications that we're in for a similar year in 2010. That's pretty high expectations, I know, in terms of these market conditions but that's who we are. So given these results in this backdrop, it's fair to add both what we're worried about and where our opportunities lie. I suspect that compared with our competitors, our worries are less significant and more manageable because of the quality of our real estate locations and the balance of our business plan as it relates to acquisitions of the past five years in new development. But we do have some level of exposure to the same type of issue as others, we still have an empty 60,000 square-foot office building over retail at Santana Row. That -- while activity has picked up greatly end of late, will be leased at far lower rents than pro forma and accordingly probably won't add a lot of value in the near term. We still have a potential great development project at Assembly Square in Boston, which everything is moving slower than planned, including IT as a construction start, resulting in more carrying costs that should lead into future profitability. And we still have the leasing headwind I discussed earlier, limiting increased core portfolio profitability.While we also have an extremely well-positioned balance sheet and presumably across the capital advantage over many other firms, both public and private on which to acquire from. At this point, we are clearly seeing more activity in terms of owners getting their heads around selling some very good and well-positioned retail real estate. We're working lots of leads and will continue to do so. The pricing remains high and sometimes unrealistically so. And as of yet, no deals that we really want are imminent. We'll remain patient, continue to focus on the blocking and tackling necessary in the core and stand ready to invest incremental capital on the right stuff for the right IRR. That's all I have for my prepared remarks right now, and I'll turn it over to Andy.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don and good morning, everyone. My comments are going to be brief this quarter, really focusing on the capital position and the assumptions of our guidance. Our long-term [indiscernible] balance sheet management including the capital raising we di
componenttext: Thanks, Don and good morning, everyone. My comments are going to be brief this quarter, really focusing on the capital position and the assumptions of our guidance. Our long-term [indiscernible] balance sheet management including the capital raising we did in '09 has positioned Trust well to run our core business and pursue additional growth opportunities through acquisitions and redevelopment. At the end of 2009, we're holding $135 million of cash. At the full $300 million of capacity available on our revolving credit facility, which is short-term funding, price of LIBOR plus 42.5, no debt maturities for a year and no need to delever the balance sheet. With respect to acquisitions, I certainly expected that we would have been able to use some of that dry powder by now. But as Don has discussed, good opportunities for high-quality properties have just not materialized yet.Given that capital market conditions have remained strong over the past six months and high-quality REITs like ourselves have been able to readily access capital, don't be surprised that we utilize some available cash and lock in longer-term debt to retire all or a portion of our $250 million prepayable term loan, if an attractive opportunity presents itself. If we were to do this, please don't see it as a change in our acquisition expectations as we still have the untapped $300 million credit facility available until July 2011. With a deal like this could allow us to improve our already strong balance sheet by further limiting our upcoming debt maturities locking in longer-term debt to historically attractive levels, all while balancing the impact to earnings.With respect to guidance, much of my surprise, we were one of the few companies which established guidance at the end of the third quarter. And we're in an even smaller minority of companies which established guidance at a range above consensus expectations for the years [ph]. We are confident that the guidance we provided in November and are just as confident today as we affirm our FFO per share guidance of $3.80 to $3.88 for 2010. The assumptions in these expectations remain pretty much unchange from last quarter and include: Same-center property operating income, that's flat to modestly positive say, 1.5% including redevelopment. This includes the impact of our latest phase of Bethesda Row development, Hampden Lane, coming on late in the year. And continual progress with Linden Square and the Balsly [ph] as the former Roche Brothers' side of the project continues to stabilize.With limited redevelopment coming online in 2010, we'd expect the gap between our including and excluding redevelopment numbers to be narrower than they have been in the past. We're continuing to run the company very leanly, since we reduced our headcount by about 20% late in 2008. Although, you may see a little fluctuation between quarters, a run rate of about $5 million per quarter is good, as we continue our focus on managing costs to the organization. We'd expect lower interest costs in '10 versus 2009, reflecting lower levels of cash balances and lower associated debt balances as the capital markets have stabilized.And just to reminder, consistent with previous quarters, we have not included the impact of any acquisitions, including the impact of expensing acquisition-related costs, prior to accounting change, it became effective on January of 2009. These costs used to be capitalized in [Audio Gap] property. Our entire team is proud of our 2009 accomplishments, and we're geared up to provide a very solid 2010. We continue to run a very balance business strategy operating on the strength of our best-in-class portfolio. Before we turn the call over to your questions, I want to echo Don's sentiments, regarding Dawn's promotion to Chief Operating Officer. Dawn and I have worked side-by-side for almost 10 years and she's been a great business partner. Even [ph] I, look forward to introducing many of you to her at future investor events. I'm confident that you'll be just as impressed as our entire team is in her ability to elevate the role. With that, Anne, I'll turn the call over to question.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy with UBS.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Don, just following up on your comments about the office building at Santana Row. This is obviously not a small project, you spent about $33 million so far. It's now expected to be a 6% yield and move back to 2011. Can you provide a bit more color on leas
componenttext: Don, just following up on your comments about the office building at Santana Row. This is obviously not a small project, you spent about $33 million so far. It's now expected to be a 6% yield and move back to 2011. Can you provide a bit more color on leasing progress there? And is this a project you wish you never started given the current environment?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Listen, do I wish we didn't start this product in the time that we did, with respect to the market? Sure, absolutely. It's a great building. It's one where we build it at a reasonable costs for out there. We do have now and the reason we moved it to a six
componenttext: Listen, do I wish we didn't start this product in the time that we did, with respect to the market? Sure, absolutely. It's a great building. It's one where we build it at a reasonable costs for out there. We do have now and the reason we moved it to a six and kind of laid out what we have is because we do have some leasing momentum, so therefore more visibility in what we're going to do. We're not there yet, but you asked about there -- fingers crossed on a full floor user in one of the three floors of the office building. And we do happen to have downstairs and on the retail side now, a little bit of a tug-of-war going between a couple of tenants that want it which is great news and has not been the case, six, nine, 12 months ago. So you're seeing some activity, we're seeing some activity for the first time but that's real. But you know what, at the end of the day, at the rents we're going to get, which are okay, but nearly what we're hoping as they would be or what they would have been at the property have been available two years ago. We're not going to make money in this building, not for a long time.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you expect to add more projects to 2011 pipeline or is Santana Row and Laurel pretty much it? And if you look ahead to how you think about projects, which projects in your shadow pipeline to undertake going forward?
componenttext: Do you expect to add more projects to 2011 pipeline or is Santana Row and Laurel pretty much it? And if you look ahead to how you think about projects, which projects in your shadow pipeline to undertake going forward?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me give you a general comment there and then I can get a little bit more specific, I do expect -- I expect that what's coming out of the past couple of years, this recession to be more opportunities on the redevelopment side. And I know I've been
componenttext: Yes. Let me give you a general comment there and then I can get a little bit more specific, I do expect -- I expect that what's coming out of the past couple of years, this recession to be more opportunities on the redevelopment side. And I know I've been saying that for a while, but I'm more confident in saying that now because we have identified additional projects that have come up because retailers are consolidating and they're consolidating to the better locations. So I don't think we've announced yet where we are. For example, at Governor, have we? Have we put Governor on it? You'll see Governor Plaza being added to this, where there is about to be a pretty good deal being done. That wasn't there before. Laurel is a real. And we've got some and, that was again because of tendencies that wants to come into the marketplace and be in a more dominant place. That we're starting to see more and more. So I would expect that redevelopment pipeline to grow throughout 2010, certainly into 2011, and be one of the key sources of our growth over the next five or seven years.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm on the line with Ross, as well, I believe he has a question.
componenttext: I'm on the line with Ross, as well, I believe he has a question.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Don used the word unreasonable to describe some of the pricing you're seeing in the investment market right now, I guess that would suggest that you think folks may be overpaying. I'm curious why you believe that's the case and what forces are out
componenttext: I think Don used the word unreasonable to describe some of the pricing you're seeing in the investment market right now, I guess that would suggest that you think folks may be overpaying. I'm curious why you believe that's the case and what forces are out there that may change that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I will tell you what I believe, and that sellers are very schizophrenic. Sellers have not really decided whether -- they show more interest, they're putting properties, non-fully marketed properties, they're talking to us and talking to others about
componenttext: Well, I will tell you what I believe, and that sellers are very schizophrenic. Sellers have not really decided whether -- they show more interest, they're putting properties, non-fully marketed properties, they're talking to us and talking to others about selling, but they haven't made the formal decision to sell. And part of that is because they're trying to figure out in the marketplace, obviously what the right costs or what the right sales prices should be. When they go and fully market for good properties, there is a feeding frenzy. There is a lot of money on the side that's chasing it. And I think supply and demand still lurks in our business. And when there is a low supply of great stuff out there. And there's a lot of money sitting on the sidelines. I think that it is not the best situation on a buyers perspective to get a great value. That is kind of what we're starting to see, what we are seeing right now. So you look at publicly marketed deals, you can be pretty sure if it's good real estate, it came down to price and it came down to a pretty good price that people we're paying maybe more than they're ultimately going to earn from an IRR perspective.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So if you're sitting here on the sidelines, not pulling the trigger right now, it would suggest that you believe that that supply demand imbalance is going to shift an impact to pricing? Or you're hoping it will?
componenttext: So if you're sitting here on the sidelines, not pulling the trigger right now, it would suggest that you believe that that supply demand imbalance is going to shift an impact to pricing? Or you're hoping it will?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm absolutely hoping it will. It comes to this, and I don't think this is any different than it's really been over the history of buying and selling real estate. You got to put money to work at incremental return to your IRR, and I really do believe that
componenttext: I'm absolutely hoping it will. It comes to this, and I don't think this is any different than it's really been over the history of buying and selling real estate. You got to put money to work at incremental return to your IRR, and I really do believe that our IRR is very favorable to many competitors. Now either we're underwriting extremely conservatively, which I don't believe that's the case. Or there is not value that's going to be provided over the long term, which is what our window is for these particular assets. And what I do think is happening, Ross, is that sellers are getting their heads around a little bit what they're able to get. I do think there needs to be a little bit of balance in terms of the money that's been sitting on the sideline that's pent up a little bit. I think that needs to get out there a little bit for there to be more of a reasonableness in terms of the buy and sell.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't -- we're talking to a lot of people on- and off-market basis and generally, the people we're talking to an off-market basis own properties that we think we wouldn't want to own. But the deals that have traded in the last year or so aren't neces
componenttext: We haven't -- we're talking to a lot of people on- and off-market basis and generally, the people we're talking to an off-market basis own properties that we think we wouldn't want to own. But the deals that have traded in the last year or so aren't necessarily deals that we would want anyway, and I just want to make that clear. What Don saying about pricing is absolutely correct, but it's not like we've been outbidding on stuff and getting outbid. Because we generally haven't seen really any deals that have traded recently that we'd want to go after that hard. We're really focused more on off-market activities right now, Ross.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the leasing and some of the metrics, we saw the pick up in occupancy in the fourth quarter and then it kind of dropped in the spreads on a cash basis. I mean, Don, I think mentioned that you could see a modest reduction in occupancy in 2010. Is th
componenttext: Just on the leasing and some of the metrics, we saw the pick up in occupancy in the fourth quarter and then it kind of dropped in the spreads on a cash basis. I mean, Don, I think mentioned that you could see a modest reduction in occupancy in 2010. Is there any color on kind of those two things, and how we think of that for run rates into this year?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would say, Paul, is a couple of things. First of all, there have been an awful lot of positive conversation from both our competitors and generally the Street about deals being done and isn't this a good thing. That there are tenants out t
componenttext: I guess, what I would say, Paul, is a couple of things. First of all, there have been an awful lot of positive conversation from both our competitors and generally the Street about deals being done and isn't this a good thing. That there are tenants out there doing deals. That is absolutely true and it is in contrast to where we were in the beginning part of the year when you just couldn't get anybody to commit to doing anything. But when you get past that, Paul, and say, well, okay, I know I can fill this space. The decision gets a lot tougher, right? The decision gets down to, well, okay, am I going to fill the space with a very low-paying tenant, who is smart and here she is going to want to lock in for the longest possible term. Or do you want to balance that decision, maybe keep the vacancy out there a little a bit longer or even risk additional vacancy. Obviously, the better the portfolio you have, the more flexibility you have in those decisions. And that is really, Paul, what I'm trying to differentiate here. In other words, I know that if our objective was to get this portfolio back to 95% leased and occupied, that I believe we could do that. I believe we could do that in relatively short order 12, 15 months. I also believe that we would be locking in deals that would hurt the value of the shopping center for a very long time. And look at me, I have no choice, you do it. We've been hearing tons about HH Gregg, everybody brings up HH Gregg as a tenant that's expanding. Well, they are. These are smart guys and they're taking advantage of the market out there. It is a lower-end product, if you will, or choice that relies of lower rents. Now if you've got no choice, you want to do an HH Gregg deal, as we did, we did one that we started earlier in the year. That is one of the biggest things in our fourth quarter number. That's bringing down our roll over growth. I'm really glad we're not talking about doing seven, eight, 10 HH Gregg deals. And that's kind of an example of what I'm referring to. I would prefer to not cut those deals so quickly, but look at the alternatives that we have there and balance them. And that's why whether we're at 93 or 92 or somewhere in that kind of range, I think it's smarter for the long-term value of the portfolio. That's the balance, I'm trying to talk about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So does that mean you're kind of getting constructive that if you're more patient that within several quarters that market rents are going to firm up, and that you'll be able to do longer-term deals at better rates?
componenttext: So does that mean you're kind of getting constructive that if you're more patient that within several quarters that market rents are going to firm up, and that you'll be able to do longer-term deals at better rates?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's what I think. And I think today, if you just kind of think back, right? There is a period of almost a year where very little is getting done other than kind of bottom feeding to just fill space. Well, there's is -- that's pent up a little bit
componenttext: Yes, that's what I think. And I think today, if you just kind of think back, right? There is a period of almost a year where very little is getting done other than kind of bottom feeding to just fill space. Well, there's is -- that's pent up a little bit and [indiscernible] aren't going to sit on the sidelines forever. And therefore, they're out now doing deals and we all feel good that there's deals out there being done. Well, once you kind of work through that a little bit, it becomes a little more normal. And I do think that rushing to fill space at poor economic for long-term deals is not, if you have any choice at all, or any prospects for a few quarters from now or a few months from now, which I think we do more than most, I think you become a little bit more patient.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding redevelopment, I mean are there cases where you have some bigger box vacancies still that might trigger some type of redevelopment opportunity on the larger scale than just the box specifically?
componenttext: Regarding redevelopment, I mean are there cases where you have some bigger box vacancies still that might trigger some type of redevelopment opportunity on the larger scale than just the box specifically?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. And one of the specific ones you're going to be seeing is Governor Plaza, for example. We do have a fully executed lease at Governor Plaza with a great retailer that really will help that shopping center return. And that is precisely in line w
componenttext: Absolutely. And one of the specific ones you're going to be seeing is Governor Plaza, for example. We do have a fully executed lease at Governor Plaza with a great retailer that really will help that shopping center return. And that is precisely in line with kind of my comments of the last couple of minutes.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Wigginton with Macquarie.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Wigginton with Macquarie.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to circle back to the acquisition topic. Historically, Federal hasn't opted to utilize joint ventures too much in your business plan. I guess, Don, give me your comments about current pricing and the supply-demand imbalance you mentioned. If t
componenttext: Just wanted to circle back to the acquisition topic. Historically, Federal hasn't opted to utilize joint ventures too much in your business plan. I guess, Don, give me your comments about current pricing and the supply-demand imbalance you mentioned. If that doesn't correct and you don't start to see more favorable pricing, would you be more open to a JV, if that's the only way you can make the numbers work?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't want you to think in any way that we don't see value in joint ventures. We obviously do. The deal we cut with Clary [ph] in a few years back has been a very good thing for Federal to do. My comment there were much more toward, and I know you
componenttext: Yes, I don't want you to think in any way that we don't see value in joint ventures. We obviously do. The deal we cut with Clary [ph] in a few years back has been a very good thing for Federal to do. My comment there were much more toward, and I know you here the word balance from me all the time, but balance of the business plan, and when you go down the route in my view of to many JVs, you've got a lot of other people competing along with common shareholders, poor decisions being made in the company with the portfolio. So we would prefer to keep our business plans simpler than that. That does not mean that I wouldn't look today, nevermind a few quarters from now today for the right JV partner to get us into markets that or extend us in the market that we're all already in and the way that we couldn't do with our own capital. It's certainly possible but you're not going to see us go running to do a bunch of JVs for that purpose because we don't think it'd be productive overall to shareholder value.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Jeff mentioned that, I think you guys are principally focusing on off-market deals and there's been a lot of, I think popular rhetoric about cap rates compressing over the last couple of months especially for A quality assets. I guess just for my own
componenttext: And Jeff mentioned that, I think you guys are principally focusing on off-market deals and there's been a lot of, I think popular rhetoric about cap rates compressing over the last couple of months especially for A quality assets. I guess just for my own enlightenment, does off-market pricing in line with on-market pricing? Or is there a disconnect there in some way? And have you seen the same type of movement in cap rates between the two types of markets that you're looking at?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, can you answer that?
componenttext: Jeff, can you answer that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. Really, no. We haven't seen a movement in cap rates in that regard really because there haven't been any transactions. I mean there's been precious few transactions in the markets where we do business. And I think it's very difficult to draw a
componenttext: Yes, David. Really, no. We haven't seen a movement in cap rates in that regard really because there haven't been any transactions. I mean there's been precious few transactions in the markets where we do business. And I think it's very difficult to draw a lot of conclusions from the transactions that have happened. We're talking to a seller on- and off-market basis, I think we're doing that primarily because we have a better chance of getting the asset in a one-on-one conversation, as opposed to spending a bunch of time chasing deals at our broker where there's a feeding frenzy in multiple bids, which is clearly occurring right now for the more certain institutional quality shopping centers in the markets where we do business that are easy to underwrite, but that's just where we rather spend our time. Do we think we would ultimately get better pricing out of that? Maybe. I think it's just more certain in getting a deal done, and it focuses us on stuff that we want to own because we think over the long term, we'll be able to add value to that real estate, not simply because the asset happens to be on the market and list it for sale at the time. So I don't know if that answers your question or not, but I just be very cautious about drawing a lot of conclusions from very small sample transactions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, The point Jeff made it's really, really important to us, is that it's not necessarily a pricing difference. It may be or may not be, but the idea of certainty versus just chasing your tail is a huge thing for us. I mean, if there's one thing this c
componenttext: David, The point Jeff made it's really, really important to us, is that it's not necessarily a pricing difference. It may be or may not be, but the idea of certainty versus just chasing your tail is a huge thing for us. I mean, if there's one thing this company does to try to do as best we can in every facets of this business is to spend time in the productive areas. And that's hard to do when you've got a lot of money sitting on the sidelines just dying to find what is perceived to be a quality product, but often isn't. The last comment I want to make on this is, I think it is the majority of shopping center real estate that is out there today that is more likely to have an NOI stream lower than the in-place NOI stream rather than higher than the NOI stream for the next five, seven, 10 years. And getting that is not real easy to do. And it does come down to us trying to figure out, us trying to only spend the time on those things, where we believe there is value to add over that timeframe as opposed to just 7.5%, grab a 7.5% current return. That's a six, seven, five, 18 months from now because the rollovers and things like that, which is a very common occurrence.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Final question on your cost of capital, I know you've talked about that pretty openly on the calls in the past. Given I know you guys, I guess issued unsecured notes last August, I mean 6% or just below I presume today, you're probably go to issue those a
componenttext: Final question on your cost of capital, I know you've talked about that pretty openly on the calls in the past. Given I know you guys, I guess issued unsecured notes last August, I mean 6% or just below I presume today, you're probably go to issue those a little bit lower. Has your view of your cost of capital changed over the past say, three or four months?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is the proverbial question. No. It is so funny. Basically, cost of capital in my view, long-term cost of capital should not change significantly on a quarter-to-quarter basis. By very definition, we should be talking about the -- we're matching long-
componenttext: This is the proverbial question. No. It is so funny. Basically, cost of capital in my view, long-term cost of capital should not change significantly on a quarter-to-quarter basis. By very definition, we should be talking about the -- we're matching long-term holds of asset with long-term costs of capital. And so short-term swings and anything really should not impact it very much and in my view, really doesn't. Now there's a separate issue and there is a -- I've said it eight and three quarters to nine or so pretty regularly as what I believe our overall cost of capital is, and I don't deviate from that. I will tell you, there are people lots of them, who disagree with me and think our overall cost of capital is 50, 75 basis points lower than that and it may be. But that is the range that we are talking about trying to create value from. And I think that puts in appropriate level cushion, if you will, to make sure that we're making the right decision.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of R.J. Milligan with Raymond James.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of R.J. Milligan with Raymond James.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow up on Paul's previous question, if you guys do see occupancy loss in 2010, what's the mix? Where do you anticipate the occupancy loss coming from? Is it small shops, national retailers, or do you think there's a possibility you lose some ten
componenttext: Just a follow up on Paul's previous question, if you guys do see occupancy loss in 2010, what's the mix? Where do you anticipate the occupancy loss coming from? Is it small shops, national retailers, or do you think there's a possibility you lose some tenants that are up for renewals and you just can't get their own rent?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's less about renewals to answer your question from the end, from the back forward. And I think it is very possibly and overall mix, I do think on small shops, you've got tenants who are sitting there trying their best to work through a tough ti
componenttext: I think it's less about renewals to answer your question from the end, from the back forward. And I think it is very possibly and overall mix, I do think on small shops, you've got tenants who are sitting there trying their best to work through a tough time. I think, as I said in the last two years, I think small shop tenants tend to hold on longer than most people think. I think they've got more flexibility in their businesses to not take pay themselves, et cetera and things like that and so they do tend to hold on. I do think to the extent, we don't see increased sales and increased consumer shopping habits consistently this year that some of them aren't going to make it. And so I think there's risk there. On the big stuff, there's always risk. I mean how long have we've been talking about borders. I don't know, right? And things like that and when you get the big guys to go, they move the numbers in a big way. So it's potentially a combination of both.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Lindsay Schroll with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Lindsay Schroll with Bank of America.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you've just wrapped up ICSC and Mid-Atlantic. Can you give us any insights into recent leasing trends or anecdotally who still working to take space?
componenttext: I know you've just wrapped up ICSC and Mid-Atlantic. Can you give us any insights into recent leasing trends or anecdotally who still working to take space?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It was certainly a much busier event than I think most people anticipated especially with the weather we just recently had here in the Mid-Atlantic region. So I think overall, it was a positive perception about what was going on. Clearly, the one trend th
componenttext: It was certainly a much busier event than I think most people anticipated especially with the weather we just recently had here in the Mid-Atlantic region. So I think overall, it was a positive perception about what was going on. Clearly, the one trend that I walk away from that's amazing to me is the focus on the department stores and how they're trying to figure out how they're going to move forward and do business and trying to steal feather from Nordstrom or the Nordstrom company in that concept. Neiman Marcus is looking at putting, rolling out the last call concept in more of their core market as opposed to outlet centers. Saks outfit is talking about the same thing. Of course, Bloomingdale has made the same kind of announcement on the outlet concept. And I've even heard rumor about Lord & Taylor thinking about it. So the one takeaway I have is just that interesting, I think they're all going to start looking at more traditional shopping centers that might align very well with Federal Realty and our ability to add something more unique to our portfolio that we haven't been able to do in the past.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I know you touched on mom and pop's, but are there any signs of things are getting any better for them, any pressure writing up?
componenttext: And then I know you touched on mom and pop's, but are there any signs of things are getting any better for them, any pressure writing up?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic, where it's been snowing for a month and a half. It's horrible that way, but and that's kind of tongue and cheek. The longer-term answer to that is yes, a little bit. Because what -- it's not so much broad-based impro
componenttext: Not in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic, where it's been snowing for a month and a half. It's horrible that way, but and that's kind of tongue and cheek. The longer-term answer to that is yes, a little bit. Because what -- it's not so much broad-based improvement, but it is a culling of those tenants that have kind of figure out how to operate on lower sales levels versus those that haven't. And they changed a bunch of different things. They changed -- you go to any restaurant, you should see the difference in the ingredients that are being used, in the portion sizes and things like that because everybody is trying to figure out how to operate their business on a lower sales level, basically. If you're asking have we seen increases in sales in any kind of a meaningful way, first of all, our knowledge is limited because of the information that we get that way. But anecdotally, the answer is probably not, in any broad way which kind of ties into the comments I was making earlier about occupancy going forward. We're certainly not out of the woods yet from an economic perspective.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010

componenttext: Maybe it was discussed earlier in all the occupancy commentary, but you mentioned to expect the 2009 leasing spreads to continue into next year. componenttext: My guess is it will come down, that we won't be able to match that in 2010. Boy, would I be bummed if it's negative and I expect it to be. So you're probably talking single digits.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the term loan, Andy, it sounds like you're thinking about maybe replacing that with some new long-term, let's say, 10-year debt. What are the pre-pay penalties for taking the term loan out early?
componenttext: And then on the term loan, Andy, it sounds like you're thinking about maybe replacing that with some new long-term, let's say, 10-year debt. What are the pre-pay penalties for taking the term loan out early?

componenttext: There aren't any pre-payment penalties. The only earnings impact would be an acceleration of pieces that we paid in order to get the term loan done, but we would've amortized through July of 2011 when it would've matured back into 2010.

componenttext: In its entirety, it's probably about $1.2 million.

componenttext: No, but depending on how we went and executed it. If, like I said in my prepared remarks, if we utilized some cash and balanced that with longer-term debt, you may be able to get it pretty close to FFO neutral.

componenttext: We and a San Francisco-based developer, Wilson Meany Sullivan, have been hired by the bank group that made the loan to the developer of Sunnyvale Town Center to advise them on what to do with the asset moving forward. And we and Wilson Meany Sullivan are being paid a fee on a monthly basis to do that.

componenttextpreview: On the acquisition front, you talked a lot about the lack of transactions for assets that Federal would like to own. And I know you've talked about a potential acquisition hit list in the past. Have any of those assets, have any of those traded yet or is
componenttext: On the acquisition front, you talked a lot about the lack of transactions for assets that Federal would like to own. And I know you've talked about a potential acquisition hit list in the past. Have any of those assets, have any of those traded yet or is that still locked up?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Nick, it's Jeff. No, nothing on our hit list has traded in the last year or so.
componenttext: Nick, it's Jeff. No, nothing on our hit list has traded in the last year or so.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Have you had any changes in conversations with sellers at this point? Are you gaining any traction on that front in terms of your off market pursuits?
componenttext: Have you had any changes in conversations with sellers at this point? Are you gaining any traction on that front in terms of your off market pursuits?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you turn the clock back 18 months or so or maybe a little bit longer when we were really in the thick of things. A lot of people just didn't want to talk at all, right, because nobody really knew where we were headed. And I think, clearly,
componenttext: Yes. I think if you turn the clock back 18 months or so or maybe a little bit longer when we were really in the thick of things. A lot of people just didn't want to talk at all, right, because nobody really knew where we were headed. And I think, clearly, the economy has kind of progressed past that point. I think the real estate capital markets have progressed past that point. And there have been a few transactions which help people to bracket values so people are more willing to engage in a discussion today than they were in, say, December of '08, right? And some of those conversations are very productive. And we're actually busy underwriting a lot of assets right now. And like Don mentioned in his comments, in his prepared remarks, some of those discussions are completely unproductive because people just have stuck in their mind this whole 5.5, 6.5 cap rate value for their assets and there hasn't been a enough transaction activity yet or they haven't thought through that enough to think that that pricing is probably not going to be achievable for a long, long time and forever. So it depends on the seller, depends on what their motivations are and where they are in their life, if you will. And it depends on whether they're private or whether they're an institution. I think the continued transaction activity will ultimately help the institutions that have been kind of sitting around on the sidelines waiting for values to stabilize, if you will, to make a sale decision. So we expect to see more institutional sellers going forward. And the private sellers, it's kind of more based on what's going on in their life with their property and maybe with the debt on their property. That's an individual discussion that's different every time you talk to a private owner.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the off market sort of activity that you're pursuing, is that a mix of different types of sellers, private and institutional?
componenttext: So in terms of the off market sort of activity that you're pursuing, is that a mix of different types of sellers, private and institutional?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, primarily private.
componenttext: Yes, primarily private.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just following up on the last line of questioning a little bit. For the deals that you're looking at, is there any specific trigger either on the private negotiations stuff or the stuff that's being marketed where you think if this happens, we'll im
componenttext: Maybe just following up on the last line of questioning a little bit. For the deals that you're looking at, is there any specific trigger either on the private negotiations stuff or the stuff that's being marketed where you think if this happens, we'll immediately see some sort of pick up and transaction flow and activities actually happening?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think there's any one specific thing. I think it's a combination of things. I think it's passage of time. I think it's more and more data point certainly help. And I think it's some recovery in the secured debt markets as well. The life compan
componenttext: No, I don't think there's any one specific thing. I think it's a combination of things. I think it's passage of time. I think it's more and more data point certainly help. And I think it's some recovery in the secured debt markets as well. The life companies have gotten more aggressive over the past few months. There's been a lot of discussion about single asset, CMBS coming back. And as that continues to evolve and mature and happen, I think that that's going to cause transaction activity to increase. My own personal opinion on that is it's going to increase to probably what we saw on the 2002, 2003, early 2004 time frame, if you look at the transaction volumes nationally. Not at the levels that we saw 2005 to early 2007 which were way in excess of any sort of transaction volume that the markets have ever witnessed before. I think we're kind of going back to where we were six, seven, eight years ago.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think when a lot of people think of Federal in the portfolio, they think of D.C. inside the Beltway, Can you talk about the different geographies and different pockets of the portfolio, whether it's up in Boston or just stuff you have in California and
componenttext: I think when a lot of people think of Federal in the portfolio, they think of D.C. inside the Beltway, Can you talk about the different geographies and different pockets of the portfolio, whether it's up in Boston or just stuff you have in California and maybe talk about the neighborhood centers versus the Street retail. Are you seeing any dramatic differences in terms of how different parts of the portfolio are performing?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I tell you, over the past few quarters, I think I've said that our Northeast portfolio, particularly the Philadelphia-based portfolio, has held up better than the rest. That remains true and that held throughout 2009. Washington, fine also. In California,
componenttext: I tell you, over the past few quarters, I think I've said that our Northeast portfolio, particularly the Philadelphia-based portfolio, has held up better than the rest. That remains true and that held throughout 2009. Washington, fine also. In California, from a geographic perspective, clearly lagging. There's no question that we have seen that sales fall off more in California than on the East Coast. That applies both to Street retail kind of stuff and the necessity-based stuff. So it's broader in terms of markets. When you get down to that other cut between traditional, necessity-based, grocery-anchored shopping centers and our other stuff, not nearly that level of difference. Certainly, somewhat worse in the lifestyle sector. But the lifestyle stuff that we own is largely established stuff that's been there. And to me, that really is the difference. If the retail -- no matter what the retail is, it has been up and operating for seven years, 10 years, longer that. They're established. They are doing better than the folks that are a year or two years or three years into their lives. That to me is the better cut more than anything else even above geography.

componenttext: I think you're right on. I'm not even going to wait on Jeff on that one. I think you're right on, Rich, in looking at it. I know everybody's impatient, but so are we. But the way you just described it, I think, is the better way to think about it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Andy about the company's $135 million of cash. Is the idea that you might use the better part of that paying down the term loan or some other debt would that just be a small component of something you do and keep the cash largely int
componenttext: I have a question for Andy about the company's $135 million of cash. Is the idea that you might use the better part of that paying down the term loan or some other debt would that just be a small component of something you do and keep the cash largely intact on the balance sheet for acquisitions that kind of thing?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean at the end of the day, when we raised all that excess cash, it was really reflective of our view of the capital markets at that time where we thought access to capital was going to be extremely tough, and we had some debts to pay down. The ben
componenttext: Yes, I mean at the end of the day, when we raised all that excess cash, it was really reflective of our view of the capital markets at that time where we thought access to capital was going to be extremely tough, and we had some debts to pay down. The benefit of holding a just-in-case capital for us right now, where we're earning practically nothing like 50 basis points, it doesn't add a lot. It still has $300 million worth of capacity on the line at LIBOR plus 42.5, and we've demonstrated access to all forms of capital through one of the toughest capital market conditions out there. So there's no need for us to hold a significant amount of excess cash. So one of the strategies that we're talking about is utilizing that excess cash along with longer-term borrowings in order to take a balanced approach to pay off that term loan.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we should think about that over the next quarter kind of thing or is that a little further down the road?
componenttext: And we should think about that over the next quarter kind of thing or is that a little further down the road?

componenttextpreview: We'll see what happens as market conditions [indiscernible] itself.
componenttext: We'll see what happens as market conditions [indiscernible] itself.

componenttext: And then on the $270 million roughly that you paid down over the quarter that you spent out of the cash. I saw where most of it went, it looked like a little bit went to an increase in investments and partnerships and then there was about $20 million that I wasn't sure where it went. Is there anything else I missed that you might have paid down or that was significant?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we paid down $122 million of the term loan. We paid down $125 million of the 8¾ notes that were coming due. What we did utilize some cash in order to pay off the loans along with our partner on a couple of JV properties. And the rest of that is jus
componenttext: Well, we paid down $122 million of the term loan. We paid down $125 million of the 8¾ notes that were coming due. What we did utilize some cash in order to pay off the loans along with our partner on a couple of JV properties. And the rest of that is just operations.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The TIs per square foot were a bit higher in the quarter. I assume that's just a sign of the times, but any thoughts on that?
componenttext: The TIs per square foot were a bit higher in the quarter. I assume that's just a sign of the times, but any thoughts on that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think it is a sign of the times. I think the key with TI is the same as it has always been, but more important now is invest it smarter, invest it in credit decisions and in companies that you've rigorously looked at. And that is our real key with T
componenttext: No, I think it is a sign of the times. I think the key with TI is the same as it has always been, but more important now is invest it smarter, invest it in credit decisions and in companies that you've rigorously looked at. And that is our real key with TI. I don't think you'll see a big trend necessarily changing, but I do think you'll when we're putting TIs in a significant way, that company's been vetted pretty hard.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nate Isbee with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nate Isbee with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Dave Fick with Nate. One, detail; can you give us an update on Assembly Square?
componenttext: It's Dave Fick with Nate. One, detail; can you give us an update on Assembly Square?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Assembly Square, we have continued to move forward from an entitlement and a planning perspective in terms of being able get the right land put together to build something one day there. The swap, if you will, with IKEA did close in the fourth quart
componenttext: Sure. Assembly Square, we have continued to move forward from an entitlement and a planning perspective in terms of being able get the right land put together to build something one day there. The swap, if you will, with IKEA did close in the fourth quarter, that was a big thing. And through that point in time, I was feeling pretty darn good. We got a call couple of weeks ago from IKEA that said, "You know what? We're not going t start building a big blue and yellow building right now because the economy stinks. I guess I shouldn't be surprised by that. But delays in development are terrible things. And so the idea of having them delay a year or two or whatever they're going to delay, we don't really have any key to that. Add more carry [ph] to the project. I do think from a valuation perspective, I kind of said this historically. I really want to make sure -- don't count on Assembly Square being a big value add for the future. I hope it will be and we'll try like crazy to get it there, but delays are not good. That's kind of where we are. All the funding remains in place, which is a great thing from both the Federal Stimulus Package and the state loan packages, which are great helps to the property. We want a blue and yellow furniture store of IKEA's quality open under construction to help be able to help the adjacent parcels which are ours, figure out what we can do there.

componenttext: We've sort of beaten the cost of capital question to death, but I'm going to make one more shot at it. The market is telling you what your equity cost of capital is, giving you an implied cap rate better than anyone else out there. Just 2008, you were buying Florida assets in the seven. If your equity is trading at an implied yield of 6.5, why does it matter? Let's just say you could buy a decent asset at an eight, but you think it's going to trade at a nine at some point as you're waiting. We're all guessing on cap rates. Why wouldn't you just go ahead buy it an eight and equitize it 100%? It's going to be accretive. It's creating value and over time, cap rates are going to move. Given your cost of capital, why won't you be the first guy out there making the transaction like that?

componenttext: Couple of things. First thing, David, there hasn't been stuff going back to just[ph] point that we want. We will not lose an asset that we want on price. Be sure of that. If there is an asset, and again, this is not -- there aren't a bunch of new assets out there that we kind of don't know about. We do run that hit list. We've done it. We know what we want out there. We're working aggressively to get those  to trade. They  haven't traded. When they do, we won't lose it on price.

componenttext: Yes, we are taking a very broad and flexible approach to how we get deals done today. Generally speaking, we know the assets that we want to buy. And we've been talking to the owners of those assets in a lot of different ways; buying outright for cash was just discussed, exchanging the properties for units or downright partnership. We've talked to owners about helping them pay down their debt when it comes time to pay down the debt and making an investment in the center to do that. We've talked to their lenders, the people that hold their mortgages. So yes, we're taking a very broad and flexible approach to how we would get at at an asset that we want in the long term.

componenttext: Yes. The answer is yes. We're always looking at it. Always. One of our biggest issues is not unlike, I guess, other people's biggest issues. So far, we haven't been particularly confident in what we've been able to -- and the fact that we find the 1031 and be able to buy. I think when you go back to Rich Moore's point of a few quarters from now, I think the conversation becomes even more relevant.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things, seven weeks in, so far so good. So that is definitely a positive signal. But in terms of the all clear, I'm not ready to declare that yet. I think we need to let this year play out a little bit. I think we need to see -- there are some
componenttext: A couple of things, seven weeks in, so far so good. So that is definitely a positive signal. But in terms of the all clear, I'm not ready to declare that yet. I think we need to let this year play out a little bit. I think we need to see -- there are some encouraging signs in the marketplace, whether they're fleeting or whether they have some more legs is yet to be determined. And anybody running a business, whether that's a retail business, a real estate business or whatever, wants to get some more certainty in terms of whether there is a recovery that's got any legs. And so some more time has to pass. I just can't give you the date.

componenttext: We'll spread it out. We'll do what we can. The ultimate for us, we want to collect the money.
