componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everybody. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilm
componenttext:
Thank you, Ahmed. Good morning, everybody. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; Jeff Berkes; and Chris Weilminster. These and other members of our management team are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. Our first quarter 2010 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trusts' operating and financial performance. The document is currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained. Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but are not limited to, future economic conditions, including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of our first quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina. Good morning, everyone. We had a very solid first quarter and it just couldn't be any clearer that better-located, higher-quality retail properties are the grouping of choice these days for most retailers, even if it costs some more to get t
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina. Good morning, everyone. We had a very solid first quarter and it just couldn't be any clearer that better-located, higher-quality retail properties are the grouping of choice these days for most retailers, even if it costs some more to get there. Every retailer that we talked to and nearly every non-real estate business in the country is more focused than ever on finding new ways to be profitable, and that newfound openness is allowing Federal to build relationships with tenants that historically wouldn't consider our various property types. Too early to tell whether we'd be able to meaningfully create demand from retailers new to us, but we're hopeful, based on initial discussions. 
This is an important point, because as we've been talking about for many quarters now, there's just too much retail supply and not enough demand nationally, and that's certainly manifesting itself in the form of lower rents and more downtime. Increasing demand by expanding the playing field is critical in more profitable deals, not just more deals. One of the reasons that I'm more bullish about the rest of the year and next year that I had been, despite the fact that many obstacles still exist in our fundamental business, and that acquisitions so far generally remain too expensive to make any money from.
Let's dissect the quarter a bit. The appropriate operational comparison for FFO was $0.94 in the first quarter of 2010, compared with $0.99 for the first quarter of 2009. And as another point of reference, $0.93 in the first quarter of '08. The $0.05 reduction from last year is more than completely due to higher interest rate caused by rate, not volume, as we work to extend the maturity of our entire debt portfolio. It couldn't move, I think, you would agree, given the likely rise in interest rates to come over time. Andy will go into more of that later. 
The bigger point that I'm trying to make though, is that this portfolio continue to generate higher operating earnings from our properties throughout this unprecedented recession of the last two years, despite lower occupancy, higher bad debt expense and unexpected rent relief. No larger impaired asset charges, no one unintended consequences from various joint venture agreements, no large severance or  restructuring charges. If we were ever tempted to move down the quality spectrum to pick up short-term yield, these results should serve as an important wake-up call that such a strategy is a short-term one. I remain convinced that acquiring a property could great exactly zero value. It's what happens to it over time that determines whether you created or destroyed value.
On the leasing front, the first quarter was a good one. We did 66 comparable deals at an average rent of $29.19, 16% more than the $25.08 that the previous tenant in that space is paying. As has been the case over the past few quarters, a few renewals of old expiring leases, both anchor and small shop offset much more pedestrian results elsewhere. A couple of market-rate options for banks at our Florida properties were renewed at big increases, as was Toys "R" Us and an old lease at Huntington Shopping Center on Long Island. Those renewals were among the largest drivers of the strong lease rollover rate. 
In addition, we signed a new deal with Dick's Sporting Goods in Glen Burnie, Maryland, as they relocated from a weaker location to act as the centerpiece of our redevelopment of Governor Plaza. Lots of tenant improvement dollars are part of that deal, which are included in our estimated returns and on the lease rollover summary. This a great deal though for both Federal and Dick's.
In terms of same set of property income growth, we reported a strong 2.9%, excluding the impact of redevelopment and 5.7% including redevelopment. Before you get excited about the 5.7%, you shouldn't, since it's impacted by the acceleration of the unamortized piece of termination fee from Home Depot at Flourtown Shopping Center that has been expected to be recorded throughout the year. It's really just timing. Even so, 3.1% growth without that impact is still very strong and benefits from easy comparisons over last year when bad debt expense was extremely high. 
Our earlier guidance of minus same store growth, I think Andy has 1% to 1½% in his model, remains unchanged for the full year. The year-over-year comparisons get much tougher for the balance of the year. 
Physical occupancy rose a bit during the quarter from 93.2% at the end of last year to 93.5% at March 31, even though the percentage leased dropped a bit to 94.1%. Owing from large bankruptcies that we don't see happening at this point, both the percentage leased and the percentage occupied, should remain fairly stable for the balance of the year. Before I turn it over to Andy, let me just touch on some development progress we're making at Santana Row. 
First, we signed our first 10-year deal for a full-floor user at 300 Santana Row, the office of retail building that we built at the corner of Stevens Creek Boulevard and the Row. We signed at least at strong economics relative to the market, but we're pretty close to a deal with a strong well-known national restaurant chain for the ground floor. We still got three floors of office to lease, but we're encouraged by both the deals and by the positive momentum that we're starting to see in the Silicon Valley office market. 
Secondly, we've just broken ground on a stand-alone 109-unit residential building at the property for $35 million, which we intend to lease as real units for a number of years and then likely sell as condominiums as dictated by the housing market. We hope to replicate the performance of the 200-loft apartment at Santana Row that we condo-ed several years back and expect an IRR well into the double digits if and when the sales are completed. 
Here in Maryland, we turned over the newly constructed building on Woodmont Avenue in Bethesda to Equinox, for opening later this year. That building is nearly 100% leased and was built on time and on budget. Jeff Berkes will be available to talk more about acquisition prospects when we open up the lines to your questions, but the bottom line remains, no deals are imminent, but the acquisition group is busier than they've been in quite some time. 
And finally, we got some great news from the judge in Arlington County, Virginia, who ruled in our favor in a lawsuit, in which we and our residential partner Post Properties sued Vornado for failing to honor our right of first offer on the land on the Pentagon Row. The judge found in our favor and ordered Vornado to sell us that land at the price they allocated to the parcel in two transactions in 2005 and 2007. We expect Vornado to appeal, but we also expect to prevail. And we impose we'll hopefully own this fee on Pentagon Row within a year, at a value that will be extremely accretive to earnings. 
I'll now turn it over to Andy, and look forward to seeing you all, at either ICSB in Las Vegas later this month, or in at maybe Chicago in early June. Andy?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. This morning, I'm going to review our financing activity for the first quarter. I'll discuss our current financial position and then go over our guidance assumptions, which are pretty much unchanged from last quarter,
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Good morning, everyone. This morning, I'm going to review our financing activity for the first quarter. I'll discuss our current financial position and then go over our guidance assumptions, which are pretty much unchanged from last quarter, before turning the call over to your questions. 
On our last call in February, I stated, we may take advantage of the improving capital markets at that time, and utilized $135 million of cash at year end to lock in longer-term debt and retire our term loan. In early March, we did exactly that, as we issued $150 million of unsecured 5.9% 10-year notes, and utilized related the proceeds, along with cash on hand to fully retire the $250 million outstanding balance on our term loan, which is set to mature in July 2011. While we did not have a prepayment penalty associated with the pay-off of our term loan, we did have to write off $2.8 million of unamortized debt fees. This expense was partially offset by the $2.3 million of income recognized in the quarter from the acceleration of The Home Depot lease termination fee at Flourtown that Don spoke about in his remarks. 
As a result of our capital market transactions throughout 2009 and into 2010 and our long-term disciplined approach to capital, our balance sheet is really in great shape, highlighted by: No debt maturities in 2010 and only $112 million of maturities in 2011; an extension of our weighted average remaining debt term by one full year to 5.7 years at March 31, 2010, compared to 4.7 years at March 31, 2009; leverage of approximately 40% as measured by debt to our low historical undepreciated asset bases; net-to-total-market capitalization of around 25%; a debt to EBITDA ratio of around 5x and a fixed charge coverage ratio in the neighborhood of 3x. 
A strong balance sheet, untapped $300 million revolving credit facility and the advantage of having a lower cost of capital within both our public and private peers will serve us well as we seek to acquire high-quality assets in our core markets. As Don said, Jeff's available to give you a little more color on the transactions environment during Q&A.
Finally, with the first three months of the year behind us and a bit more clarity on the rest of the year, we've increased our 2010 FFO per share guidance to a range of $3.82 to $3.89. The assumptions in this guidance are largely unchanged from last quarter, but include full year same center property income growth of around 1½%, including redevelopment, unchanged from last quarter. Yes, the full year growth rate is lower than our same center growth reported in the first quarter are resulting from tougher comps for the remainder of 2010. 
Lower interest costs for the full year of 2010 versus 2009 totaling around $7 million to $8 million in interest savings, including the fees and costs associated with the early pay-off of our term loan in March, largely resulting from eliminating the excess cash that we were holding over the past nine months, reflected in the dramatic improvement in capital market conditions. 
Finally, as always, we've not included the impact of any acquisitions in our guidance. We feel confident going to the second quarter of the year that 2010 will be another solid year for Federal Realty. We continue to run a very balanced business strategy, operating on the strength of our best-in-class property portfolio, while prudently evaluating opportunities for growth. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to your questions. Ahmed, if we can start polling for questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Have you seen any other reason, improvement in consumer sentiment and spending translate into an increase in discussions with potential tenants regarding space needs? We've heard some folks that retailers are getting worried that with no new supply growth
componenttext: Have you seen any other reason, improvement in consumer sentiment and spending translate into an increase in discussions with potential tenants regarding space needs? We've heard some folks that retailers are getting worried that with no new supply growth, they're going to run out of expansion options by 2012. Are you hearing or seeing that at all? Any changes in the last couple of months?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: A little bit, Christy, yes. I mean, look, the one thing that has absolutely changed is the sentiment to do deals. And almost every retailer, because they haven't been doing anything for a year, year and a half, feel some pent-up pressure here. Now that's
componenttext: A little bit, Christy, yes. I mean, look, the one thing that has absolutely changed is the sentiment to do deals. And almost every retailer, because they haven't been doing anything for a year, year and a half, feel some pent-up pressure here. Now that's not translating really into deals that are great economically all over the place, because they still have plenty of choices. But yes, there is far more demand. What'll be interesting in the period of time you're talking about is, listen, development has recently been shut down for some period of time now, and so, there are less options particularly, among the nationals to be able to expand the development projects. But there are plenty of other places that they can go. So I haven't heard it translating into worry in any respect, that way, but they're clearly more optimistic.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to the center and adjacent building in Norwalk, Connecticut, where you hold the mortgages that are in default, I understand you've consolidated the assets. But what ultimately happens with them from your perspective once they're foreclosed on?
componenttext: With regard to the center and adjacent building in Norwalk, Connecticut, where you hold the mortgages that are in default, I understand you've consolidated the assets. But what ultimately happens with them from your perspective once they're foreclosed on? Is there potential opportunity there, given the investment you have?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, there is. I mean, the idea of basically owning a Loehman's Shopping Center in Norwalk, Connecticut, while not a big development, which is was initially potentially could be, because there were a lot of adjacent parcels. We didn't get nor do
componenttext: Yes, I think, there is. I mean, the idea of basically owning a Loehman's Shopping Center in Norwalk, Connecticut, while not a big development, which is was initially potentially could be, because there were a lot of adjacent parcels. We didn't get nor do we really want at this point, the adjacent parcels. But there is a pretty decent shopping center that's sitting there that could be redeveloped over time, once we get control of it and can evaluate it more. So I view that as a good thing.

componenttext: It's low, it's a few percent. I don't know, is it 3% or 4%? I think, I'm looking at Jeff, it's actually 4% or 5% or so to start. But they are things that we can do to bring that up to a good yield.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Wigginton with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Wigginton with Macquarie.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, from your commentary, and I guess, from commentary we're hearing from other folks in the space and even in the private side, it seems that it's becoming increasingly evident that the highly accretive acquisition opportunities are going to be few and
componenttext: Don, from your commentary, and I guess, from commentary we're hearing from other folks in the space and even in the private side, it seems that it's becoming increasingly evident that the highly accretive acquisition opportunities are going to be few and far in between. I guess, are you as optimistic as say, you were on your last quarter's call? Or are you less optimistic that you'll be able to find some accretive acquisition opportunities maybe this year and even in 2011?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: David, am I as bullish that we'll be able to put a $1 billion to work which was I said before over the next four years? Yes. I'm in the same place about that. Now will they be as short-term accretive? No, because I think, values are very high, and which i
componenttext: David, am I as bullish that we'll be able to put a $1 billion to work which was I said before over the next four years? Yes. I'm in the same place about that. Now will they be as short-term accretive? No, because I think, values are very high, and which is why we're not just jumping and doing anything. When we do, do something, you'll like the real estate a lot. But I do not think it will be initially as accretive as we all kind of initially thought it would be a year ago, a year and a half ago. But I do think, there's a big change happening in terms of sellers putting properties out there, really considering selling, and I do think we'll be able to accomplish it. I think, you should expect to see an acquisition or two this year and then more next. And then maybe I'll just turn it over to Jeff at this point. It's probably a good place to get into kind of what we're seeing more broadly on the acquisition side.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, the pipeline that we're working on right now is probably as deep as it's ever been. And I think, there's been a clear sentiment shift in the last two, three, four, five months. And sellers are a lot more willing to engage in discussions about
componenttext: Yes, David, the pipeline that we're working on right now is probably as deep as it's ever been. And I think, there's been a clear sentiment shift in the last two, three, four, five months. And sellers are a lot more willing to engage in discussions about parting with their property today than they were two, three, four, five months ago. And I think, I attribute that to a couple of things. One is some transactions have happened, and as we've talked about on past calls, I think, that's very good for the market. That gives sellers another's confidence with respect to bringing their property to the market, and more transactions that happen, the better, and that momentum kind of builds on it. So we're starting to see that now. Clearly, the fact that there's some clarity in an economic recovery or some early signs of an economic recovery, I think, are making it easier for people to make a sell decision. And then finally, the availability of mortgage debt capital is much greater than it was three, six, nine, certainly 12 months ago, and that's making a lot easier for sellers to get their heads around bringing their property to market now. So the momentum is really favorable on the activities picked up significantly. And we're busy underwriting a lot of stuff right now, most of which were in direct conversations with sellers on as opposed to poorly marketed properties. But the trend is good.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me add one thing to that, David, from a modeling perspective. Remember that since the last period of time, when there were significant amount of acquisitions out there, the accounting rules have changed. And so virtually, all your costs associated wit
componenttext: Let me add one thing to that, David, from a modeling perspective. Remember that since the last period of time, when there were significant amount of acquisitions out there, the accounting rules have changed. And so virtually, all your costs associated with going after that acquisition are now going to be expensed but not capitalized in some projects. So I think, there'll very few high-quality properties that are purchased that are accretive in the first year, for two reasons. Not only because of the higher volumes, values which hammer down cap rates, but also because of the expensing of the initial cost of getting the acquisition. But we look at this stuff. We have and will continue to look at this stuff on an IRR basis. Since coming out of this recession, we'd love to be able to increase the size of the platform of great quality real estate.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, just back to your comments on why you think sellers or owners are becoming more willing to sell. I would imagine the compression in cap rates has something to do with that as well. But in light of that, I mean, how much would you say the cap rates h
componenttext: Jeff, just back to your comments on why you think sellers or owners are becoming more willing to sell. I would imagine the compression in cap rates has something to do with that as well. But in light of that, I mean, how much would you say the cap rates have compressed since year-end 2009 now, on the types of properties that you're looking at?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a hard question to answer, because of the types of properties that we look at and that we want to buy, none of those really traded, right? What's traded has been different than what we want to buy. So that's not an easy question to answer, with the
componenttext: That's a hard question to answer, because of the types of properties that we look at and that we want to buy, none of those really traded, right? What's traded has been different than what we want to buy. So that's not an easy question to answer, with the data, or certainly, with many data points. But if you want a range, I'd say it's 100 basis points or so. But again, that's not based on a lot of data.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: David, this is Don. The one other question, I think, we're talking about with respect to box rents, one of the issues with sellers who were selling shopping centers with boxes in them is that what we're finding is that many sellers have really not come to
componenttext: David, this is Don. The one other question, I think, we're talking about with respect to box rents, one of the issues with sellers who were selling shopping centers with boxes in them is that what we're finding is that many sellers have really not come to grips with the notion that the $22, $24, $26 a foot in-place rents from existing boxes are not able to replicate it, to the extent those boxes go away. And so those kind of box centers, particularly, which have great income stream today and would be bought at terrific cap rates today, the problem is we could never underwrite those at growing and aligning streams because those box change, there's no question. The box rents are significantly below many of the in-place rents that are there. So that's another complicating factor when you talk about cap rates.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Andy, on the lease terms from Home Depot, I assume that's incurred in another property income. How much was that?
componenttext: Andy, on the lease terms from Home Depot, I assume that's incurred in another property income. How much was that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: That was $2.3 million. I think, as Don said in his remarks, that's neutral for the year. That's just income that we're going to receive through the remainder of the year, that we're now receiving in the first quarter.
componenttext: That was $2.3 million. I think, as Don said in his remarks, that's neutral for the year. That's just income that we're going to receive through the remainder of the year, that we're now receiving in the first quarter.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: On the TIs for the quarter, the total amount was down but the TI amount per square foot was fairly high, it sounds like it was related to Dick's at Governor. But can you just help reconcile the I guess, the TI per square foot versus -- I mean, I think tha
componenttext: On the TIs for the quarter, the total amount was down but the TI amount per square foot was fairly high, it sounds like it was related to Dick's at Governor. But can you just help reconcile the I guess, the TI per square foot versus -- I mean, I think that the amount of TIs was lower in the first quarter than it had been in the fourth and third quarters of last year?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, no question about it, Dave. But it's all based on the particular deals that are done in the quarter. And so you'll see that going up and down. And that's really no different than you've seen over the past bunch of years. We are certainly much more wi
componenttext: Yes, no question about it, Dave. But it's all based on the particular deals that are done in the quarter. And so you'll see that going up and down. And that's really no different than you've seen over the past bunch of years. We are certainly much more willing to do a deal like this, which is repositioning a shopping center and put a big TI number in there and invest, if you will, on that shopping center. And so that is a big driver to that number this quarter. If you look at our breakdown, when we break out new leases and renewals, you'll see very much that the TI number comes from the new leases as opposed to the renewals. And when we do a new lease, and we have made the determination that we are willing to invest, if you will, in that retailer, that all goes to the investment committee and is included in the financial analysis of what the viability of the deal. So Dick's, it's another one or two deals, similarly for some great tenants to reposition shopping centers.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the activity on the office side at Santana and there's been a lot of anecdotes in Silicon Valley over the past couple of months. I mean, do you think that maybe the activity on the three remaining vacant floors could materialize into somethi
componenttext: You mentioned the activity on the office side at Santana and there's been a lot of anecdotes in Silicon Valley over the past couple of months. I mean, do you think that maybe the activity on the three remaining vacant floors could materialize into something sooner rather than later, now that we've seen this improvement?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd love to say yes, but practically speaking, I don't think so. I think, new office builds take a lot of time. And while there is positive momentum in the Valley, taking positive momentum and getting that through all the available choices and cutting a d
componenttext: I'd love to say yes, but practically speaking, I don't think so. I think, new office builds take a lot of time. And while there is positive momentum in the Valley, taking positive momentum and getting that through all the available choices and cutting a deal is certainly going to take time. You're not going to see any income, for example, in '10 from other than the lease that we just did that will start at the end of the year. But you're not going to see any other income on that building in 2010, for example. So no, I wouldn't move up -- I would not change my assumptions or my timing of that. It's just that we see a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel in terms of the pool of prospective tenants that we didn't see six months ago.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: For the small shops, I mean, are there any patterns of activity from a leasing perspective, segments where you have seen a clear improvement in interest versus some of those where you're actually still sort of net losers of space?
componenttext: For the small shops, I mean, are there any patterns of activity from a leasing perspective, segments where you have seen a clear improvement in interest versus some of those where you're actually still sort of net losers of space?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I got to tell you, and I'll turn it over to Chris, in case he wants to add anything to this. But in analyzing all the deals we do, quarter in quarter out, the difference is the quality of the real estate and not the category. I've never been so sure of th
componenttext: I got to tell you, and I'll turn it over to Chris, in case he wants to add anything to this. But in analyzing all the deals we do, quarter in quarter out, the difference is the quality of the real estate and not the category. I've never been so sure of that comment as they're coming through the last couple of years. It is so much more about any retailer in any category, trying to do business and upgrade the quality of their real estate locations far more than any category. I don't know, Chris?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I agree with you completely, Don. I don't think there's any true trend. The only thing that I see to be interesting right now is some of the soft-goods players that were on complete hold 18 months ago, the smaller guys, they guys that are in the 2,000 to
componenttext: I agree with you completely, Don. I don't think there's any true trend. The only thing that I see to be interesting right now is some of the soft-goods players that were on complete hold 18 months ago, the smaller guys, they guys that are in the 2,000 to 4,000 square-foot range. And I think, they completely stopped their pipeline of new deals, are now out looking. And there's more of those retailers looking, which is nice to see soft-goods players that are out there in the market, that we hope we can do some transactions with. I think, that will really help Santana Row in some respect, with some of our other properties that are soft-goods driven.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Don, based on what you were saying there, I mean, have you poached many retailers? Or is this retailer sort of looking to add a store in a higher kind of demographic location?
componenttext: And then Don, based on what you were saying there, I mean, have you poached many retailers? Or is this retailer sort of looking to add a store in a higher kind of demographic location?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's a combination of both. But I mean, I don't -- would be meaning to keep saying Dick's at Governor over and over again. But Dick's at Governor is a great poaching, if you will, from a poor-quality center to this one. That stuff happens. Now it happ
componenttext: No, it's a combination of both. But I mean, I don't -- would be meaning to keep saying Dick's at Governor over and over again. But Dick's at Governor is a great poaching, if you will, from a poor-quality center to this one. That stuff happens. Now it happens more often at some of the smaller tenants. But it's, right now, there is the desire to grow, for retailers to go back to growing their business. So I don't want to say, it's all poaching, because it's not all poaching. It's mostly tenants now starting to do new stores. But poaching has allowed us to strengthen shopping centers that we wouldn't have been able to strengthen a couple of years back. That's the benefit of that, even though you look at the yields of a Dick's or of an LA Fitness, which we have, I think, on our schedule at Laurel Shopping Center. When you specifically just look at the deal, are you making a ton of money on the deal? No. But what are you doing to the cap rate of the shopping center in improving the balance of the tenancy there? It's just very significant. So poaching's a component, but it's mostly new deals.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted go back to Christy's question on the Norwalk asset. Are there other sort of materially other centers, where you guys only either are a mezz or a mortgage position? And then is this something that you feel is maybe a better way to get involved
componenttext: Just wanted go back to Christy's question on the Norwalk asset. Are there other sort of materially other centers, where you guys only either are a mezz or a mortgage position? And then is this something that you feel is maybe a better way to get involved in an asset versus straight trying to go after the C?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: There were not others, where we had that situation. That was specifically done, because we're looking at a larger development at that particular property. With respect to going after the debt base, going to get the equity, that's tough to do. We kind of d
componenttext: There were not others, where we had that situation. That was specifically done, because we're looking at a larger development at that particular property. With respect to going after the debt base, going to get the equity, that's tough to do. We kind of do things backwards here. We truly look at the properties that we want to control, not the other way around. We don't look at what's available for sale and try to do is deal as much as we go up far ahead and let's see what we want to own, to the extent we've got the ability at one of the properties that we want to control, that is on our hit list to maybe take a piece of the debt, maybe provide some mezzanine financing and in a way to get to that asset, sure, we'd look at it. Will that be kind of the primary way that we build this portfolio? I would say no.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me just, Alex, be clear on one thing. I mean if we did something like that, if we did a mezzanine piece or a preferred equity piece, yes, we wouldn't be doing that with the intent of acquiring ownership through some default on that financing instrumen
componenttext: Let me just, Alex, be clear on one thing. I mean if we did something like that, if we did a mezzanine piece or a preferred equity piece, yes, we wouldn't be doing that with the intent of acquiring ownership through some default on that financing instrument. We would, as part of our deal, structure the right -- to have a right of first negotiation or right of first refusal to buy the property if the seller ever did decide to sell it. We're not looking for opportunities for involuntary ownership.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then Don, in your opening remarks, you spoke about a lot of or a number of new tenants, tenants who traditionally weren't part of your portfolio were now considering it. If we think back during the boom years, it seem like there was almost a blurring
componenttext: And then Don, in your opening remarks, you spoke about a lot of or a number of new tenants, tenants who traditionally weren't part of your portfolio were now considering it. If we think back during the boom years, it seem like there was almost a blurring between malls, lifestyle outlets, shopping centers and you sort of had tenants crossing different property types. Can you just sort of contrast what's going on now versus the sort of feeding frenzy that we went through a few years ago?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's driven by a little different desire right now, but I very much believe this can have a similar effect. And that is -- look, it's pretty expensive to operate in the mall these days. And as great outlets are, there's a real limited supply
componenttext: Yes, I think it's driven by a little different desire right now, but I very much believe this can have a similar effect. And that is -- look, it's pretty expensive to operate in the mall these days. And as great outlets are, there's a real limited supply to them. To the extent, you can take a portfolio like Federal's, which is generally larger assets, right, our average asset is 225,000 or 230,000 square feet. It's not a 125,000 square foot strip center, for example, so generally larger assets, generally higher quality assets. We think we could provide an alternative to retails who are struggling to figure out how to make the mall model work, and so we're meeting with a lot of these tenants. And maybe over the next quarter or two, I'll have more to tell you about whether there's something there or not.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the litigation of Pentagon Row, given how litigation can sort of drag on for a long time, you seem to suggest that it may be resolved within the coming year. What gives you that confidence?
componenttext: Just on the litigation of Pentagon Row, given how litigation can sort of drag on for a long time, you seem to suggest that it may be resolved within the coming year. What gives you that confidence?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Our lawyers, the court that we happen to be doing business in, the process for appeal. It's not even likely from what we understand that Grenada will get the chance to appeal. Basically, 30% or so in this particular jurisdiction of cases are granted the r
componenttext: Our lawyers, the court that we happen to be doing business in, the process for appeal. It's not even likely from what we understand that Grenada will get the chance to appeal. Basically, 30% or so in this particular jurisdiction of cases are granted the right to appeal and 70% are turned down. It all gets down to the very detailed legal pieces notions of the case, and we feel really good about it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sloan Bohlen with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sloan Bohlen with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm on with Jay as well. Don and Jeff, just a question on acquisitions, and you talked about not a lot out there being accretive probably in year one. If you're out there looking for a deal and potentially, there's a lease-up opportunity or a redevelopmen
componenttext: I'm on with Jay as well. Don and Jeff, just a question on acquisitions, and you talked about not a lot out there being accretive probably in year one. If you're out there looking for a deal and potentially, there's a lease-up opportunity or a redevelopment opportunity, what's a good time for when you would be looking to lease that space up or what's the ideal acquisition to get to that IRR?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean -- and we are looking at some of it exactly what you're referring to right now. And so when you're talking lease-up, the seller will have the whole thing leased-up in the next nine months and we'll say, well, no, it's probably 18. And on redevelopm
componenttext: I mean -- and we are looking at some of it exactly what you're referring to right now. And so when you're talking lease-up, the seller will have the whole thing leased-up in the next nine months and we'll say, well, no, it's probably 18. And on redevelopments, we know that it will take a few years. So certainly, the IRRs that we look at, we look at a 10-year IRR basically as what we're trying to do. You'll certainly see, depending on the property, kind of low yields for the first year or two and pretty much very acceptable by year three and certainly by year four.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow on to Paul's question from earlier about the smaller shop tenants. Is there a strategy and I don't know to what degree you can do things practically, but it's a little bit higher role I guess in 2011 and 2012 for that space, just on
componenttext: And then just a follow on to Paul's question from earlier about the smaller shop tenants. Is there a strategy and I don't know to what degree you can do things practically, but it's a little bit higher role I guess in 2011 and 2012 for that space, just on the expiration?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Give me the question again. I'm not sure, I get you.
componenttext: Give me the question again. I'm not sure, I get you.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just for looking ahead at the lease expirations for small shop space in the coming years, it's just a little bit higher?
componenttext: Sure. Just for looking ahead at the lease expirations for small shop space in the coming years, it's just a little bit higher?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: About [ph] (01:24:03) the schedules?
componenttext: About [ph] (01:24:03) the schedules?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we get that question almost every quarter. And at the end of the day, it's really just a mix of tenants that are uniquely rolling in any particular quarter. It's not -- you need to think about it. The rents -- that certain properties are sign
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we get that question almost every quarter. And at the end of the day, it's really just a mix of tenants that are uniquely rolling in any particular quarter. It's not -- you need to think about it. The rents -- that certain properties are significantly higher than they are and others. And those specific group of deals that are rolling in any one year are what drive that. It's not a matter of that's going to create easier or tougher comps with respect to rollover. It's just very space specific.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a perfect example. Santana Row now, for example, was opened in 2002. Lot of tenured deals in there, lots of stuff renewing in 2012. General rates at Santana Row are higher than the rest of our portfolio and yet we're still feeling very goo
componenttext: Let me give you a perfect example. Santana Row now, for example, was opened in 2002. Lot of tenured deals in there, lots of stuff renewing in 2012. General rates at Santana Row are higher than the rest of our portfolio and yet we're still feeling very good about the way portfolio some of those spaces would roll, and not so good about how others would roll, so it will depend on the particular deal.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was just going to say that as well. I mean think we've been conservative on how we've been renewing tenants over the past 18 months when it was more of a tenant market and it'd be down in shorter term and all that are showing up in there as well. S
componenttext: Yes, I was just going to say that as well. I mean think we've been conservative on how we've been renewing tenants over the past 18 months when it was more of a tenant market and it'd be down in shorter term and all that are showing up in there as well. So it help take advantage of a lot of being tied in the market down [ph] (01:25:23) , so some of that was self-driven too.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Given the attractive cap rates for some of the higher quality strip real estate, have you altered your outlook towards dispositions in the next year or two?
componenttext: Given the attractive cap rates for some of the higher quality strip real estate, have you altered your outlook towards dispositions in the next year or two?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a fair question, and it's tied a little bit to acquisitions with us because certainly, there are assets that we would sell. But virtually anything that we would sell has a big built-in tax gain. And so the ability to 1031, the ability to handle the
componenttext: That's a fair question, and it's tied a little bit to acquisitions with us because certainly, there are assets that we would sell. But virtually anything that we would sell has a big built-in tax gain. And so the ability to 1031, the ability to handle the tax costs associated with it would have to be done well. And so as you see us buying more, you may see us also selling some of those properties to the extent that the market timing works. You'd look at us over for a long,  long time and for a good period of time, there are about $50 million a year or so, we would regularly dispose of, and I'd like to get back to that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you'd like something like the Laurel project once you put in LA Fitness...
componenttext: Well, I think you'd like something like the Laurel project once you put in LA Fitness...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Stop dissing, Laurel. We like Laurel.
componenttext: Stop dissing, Laurel. We like Laurel.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just saying, maybe you've done as much as you can for centers is great. It's going to do well, but maybe your money is better spent at a center that has a little more opportunity.
componenttext: I'm just saying, maybe you've done as much as you can for centers is great. It's going to do well, but maybe your money is better spent at a center that has a little more opportunity.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I don't disagree with that at all. I just like to get a little bit more comfortable with those opportunities.
componenttext: Yes. No, I don't disagree with that at all. I just like to get a little bit more comfortable with those opportunities.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of investments going forward, do you think that redevelopment will be more important than acquisitions or vice versa, in terms of money spent?
componenttext: In terms of investments going forward, do you think that redevelopment will be more important than acquisitions or vice versa, in terms of money spent?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think redevelopment will be more steady and acquisitions will be more optimistic. And so -- gosh, it was a long time ago now, but we felt pretty comfortable in telling you that we could put $75 million of work each year in redevelopment and we did that
componenttext: I think redevelopment will be more steady and acquisitions will be more optimistic. And so -- gosh, it was a long time ago now, but we felt pretty comfortable in telling you that we could put $75 million of work each year in redevelopment and we did that for a long time. I kind of see us getting back to that a little bit. Now before you run out and put $75 million in every model for the next five years that way, that is a key part of being able to add value in shopping center, so it's always going to be a key part of our business plan. Acquisitions are far more opportunistic and you may see a year where we're doing $400 million or $500 million and in other year where we do none, and that will continue there. So I'm not sure I can really say one is more important than the other, but one is certainly more steady than the other.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010

And I guess I'm curious about what the earliest is that you might be [ph] (01:28:42) to expand capital on a Phase I of that property?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, same on us that we can't make money on Mid-Pike, because it's truly the best piece of land, development land, certainly in the portfolio. And the White Flint sector plan has been approved this month which is a huge, big start, a great s
componenttext: Yes, first of all, same on us that we can't make money on Mid-Pike, because it's truly the best piece of land, development land, certainly in the portfolio. And the White Flint sector plan has been approved this month which is a huge, big start, a great start being able to get to have far more density and FAR on the segment. So we're going to have that. Now what we're able to build and when, we're still working through. But the early issue should see stuff under construction is really two years from now. So if there's a Phase I, which we're kind of working through right now, that puts some money to work in 2012 with an opening at '13, or the end of '13, '14, something like that. That's the first phase. Mid-Pike itself will be 10, 12, 15 years. I hope we're talking about Mid-Pike forever, in terms of the ability to add more and more and more there. You know we won't do -- you're never going to see us take a project and just say, "Boom! That's the form." And so we've got a very productive shopping center there albeit visually challenged in terms of its architecture. But to the extent we can do a first base there in a couple of years while keeping the balance of the center up and then incrementally adding over time between then and there, that's kind of what I think you should expect at Mid-Pike.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The switch coast that Santana, similarly, it looks like you're going forward on a residential component, do you contemplate leasing the residential you're look at building there as multifamily initially, and like the other parts of the project, later conv
componenttext: The switch coast that Santana, similarly, it looks like you're going forward on a residential component, do you contemplate leasing the residential you're look at building there as multifamily initially, and like the other parts of the project, later converting into condos or...

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: We do, Jeff. And I'll tell you, the one thing about Santana, I know you've been there and kind of get it. It is a city within itself, and the one thing that is incredibly hard to do and not something we really want to do is time the condo market.  It's th
componenttext: We do, Jeff. And I'll tell you, the one thing about Santana, I know you've been there and kind of get it. It is a city within itself, and the one thing that is incredibly hard to do and not something we really want to do is time the condo market.  It's there when it's there, it's not there when it's not. But Santana itself produces such a good foundation in base that by building -- and we came to this, obviously after talking to partners and lots of other people and trying to time it here and there. We said, "We've got to have product up there and residential product particularly." It's a very attractive place to live. Residential product that we'll put up, we will lease as for rent apartments, certainly get a return that is acceptable for that type of product. And then when the market is appropriate, we will build a two-condo spec and be able to convert it. That's how -- we made more money doing that at Santana back on this first 200 units than on any other single-time transaction there. And so that model we think should work and maybe to the extent it works the way we hoped well on its first building, you'll see more of that too.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know I recognize it's all in the margin because you effectively took your land cost and you acquired and built those projects out in Phase I. But can you talk a little bit about how you're seeing that because since the land is already been arguably
componenttext: Yes, I know I recognize it's all in the margin because you effectively took your land cost and you acquired and built those projects out in Phase I. But can you talk a little bit about how you're seeing that because since the land is already been arguably you're are -- knowing that the rents are there, even condo prices are there within Santana. I mean we've seen that you're developing to what could be sort of mid-upper teen IRRs?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, that's exactly right and I think I've said that in the prepared remarks. Obviously, the initial unlevered yields from a rental property won't be that, they'll be in the sixes, some kind of number like that, which is frankly fine. But to the extent we
componenttext: No, that's exactly right and I think I've said that in the prepared remarks. Obviously, the initial unlevered yields from a rental property won't be that, they'll be in the sixes, some kind of number like that, which is frankly fine. But to the extent we turn that three, four, five years into condos for exactly the reasons you just said, you should expect mid- to upper teen IRRs. We do.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm flipping coast, is that in Assembly Square,  I noticed like the city some of those releasing capital to begin roadway improvements and frankly the T-stop discussion seemed to be coming faster than I would have expected.  What's the earliest I guess yo
componenttext: I'm flipping coast, is that in Assembly Square,  I noticed like the city some of those releasing capital to begin roadway improvements and frankly the T-stop discussion seemed to be coming faster than I would have expected.  What's the earliest I guess you guys would consider maybe selling of entitlements to developers to explore the residential or the office component of that side? Is that two, three years away, or is that far too premature?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's not far too premature. In fact, we've got an offering memorandum out there now on the very first base on the residential side. Well, we certainly don't want to do anything until we're sure that there's a T-stop there. But as you say, boy, that's
componenttext: No, it's not far too premature. In fact, we've got an offering memorandum out there now on the very first base on the residential side. Well, we certainly don't want to do anything until we're sure that there's a T-stop there. But as you say, boy, that's looking better and better. To the extent there is a T-stop there, there should be a residential market. So we're testing that right now in terms of seeing what we can figure out on that side. We know that there is strong, strong demand for a theater there now. We know that there is strong, strong demand for theater there now. We know that there is strong demand for restaurants there. We know those things. Now, what more retail could be there? We still have work to do and to get comfortable with. What the value of the residential entitlements will be there? We still have more work to do. But as I say, well, really in the next few months, have a better idea of the residential side of that. And we would look, we're looking for the right partner on the residential side.

componenttext: Yes, we have. We're actively bidding on several assets right now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And is the issue just being up bid or they're just being pulled back by the seller? What are the issues there?
componenttext: And is the issue just being up bid or they're just being pulled back by the seller? What are the issues there?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't bid in a fully-brokered auction-type process on any deals, so we haven't been outbid. The issue is quite frankly, what it always is and always has been for the kind of real estate we want to buy and don't care whether it's 2010 or 2004. When I
componenttext: We haven't bid in a fully-brokered auction-type process on any deals, so we haven't been outbid. The issue is quite frankly, what it always is and always has been for the kind of real estate we want to buy and don't care whether it's 2010 or 2004. When I started here doing this in 1997, there's always a gap that needs to be closed between the buyer and seller and that takes work. And it's just a function of the type of asset really that we want to buy, which is a high-quality asset that down the road we think we can add value to through redevelopment, leasing and intensive asset management. And the people that own those kinds of properties know they're good properties and there's always work to do to close that gap. And as Don mentioned, I mean one of the impediments that's maybe new to where we are in the cycle right now is, I think the box leasing environment was impacted maybe indefinitely by the recession. And there are still a lot of owners that don't understand the new dynamics of box leasing today. So when those centers when we have a box that maybe is not doing or a box tenant, that maybe is not doing the kind of sales that we'd like to see or has a near-term lease expiration, or some other opportunity to come back and take a whack at the rent that they're currently paying, that's creating a lot of the gap between what we'd like to pay for an asset right now and what the seller thinks it's worth.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Then, Don, as you guys head to ICSC, do you have specific sort of corporate goals that you're looking to achieve whether that be new tenant relationships, leasing velocity, acquisition activity, anything that you're sort of targeting as you head into that
componenttext: Then, Don, as you guys head to ICSC, do you have specific sort of corporate goals that you're looking to achieve whether that be new tenant relationships, leasing velocity, acquisition activity, anything that you're sort of targeting as you head into that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you just said our three corporate goal. New tenant relationships, acquisition opportunities -- no, listen, there's -- ICSC, what ICSC has become, it really is the kind of the place the headquarters of everything that is shopping centers. And so Je
componenttext: I think you just said our three corporate goal. New tenant relationships, acquisition opportunities -- no, listen, there's -- ICSC, what ICSC has become, it really is the kind of the place the headquarters of everything that is shopping centers. And so Jeff has a very full schedule out there with potential sellers. Chris and his team have a very full schedule of specific deals at specific properties that they're working through. We certainly are using it to -- some other meetings around it, to increase our tenant relationships and with folks that we're trying to do that with. And we're also showcasing a number of properties out there that we think have significant benefits to them or significant upside to them, including the initial stuff that we're talking about for Assembly Square and the redevelopment properties. So this is going to be a very, very busy. And if the early signs are right, a very productive ICSC.

componenttext: Can you give us an update on the Super Fresh situation at Rockville?

componenttextpreview: I can't. There won't be one. At Rockville Town Square, Super Fresh has come back and said they're not going to open a grocery store there. As you may or may not know, they've gone through another management change. They have a new CEO. They have been payi
componenttext: I can't. There won't be one. At Rockville Town Square, Super Fresh has come back and said they're not going to open a grocery store there. As you may or may not know, they've gone through another management change. They have a new CEO. They have been paying us full rent. In fact, better than full rent since that store did not open, but since the requirements start paying rent did. But they're working to find a tenant to take over their obligation, and we are now working very aggressively to find a tenant to take over their obligation. But that lease will be backstopped by them. So that rent is not at risk.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we may have the whole cap rate discussion to death but I want to take another shot. Given your cost of capital, isn't the market sort of telling you where high-quality real estate valuations are going? And given that probably wouldn't have substan
componenttext: I think we may have the whole cap rate discussion to death but I want to take another shot. Given your cost of capital, isn't the market sort of telling you where high-quality real estate valuations are going? And given that probably wouldn't have substantially dilute quality to reduce your cap rate targets, why doesn't it make sense to fully equitize deals again, considering that you're clearly in the sixes in terms of where you're trading today?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it does, David. I think, though, the trick is to get the property that you want. And not just do it to do it, you've got to find the right real estate. And I think, David, it was your comment last time, love the discipline where the growth. And I
componenttext: I think it does, David. I think, though, the trick is to get the property that you want. And not just do it to do it, you've got to find the right real estate. And I think, David, it was your comment last time, love the discipline where the growth. And I suspect that's kind of where you're going again today, which I completely agree with but we are not going to dilute the quality of the real estate that we own. So it's just about freeing up the stuff we want.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: When you're looking at the portfolio in terms of the performance, whether it be on a spread basis, sales performance basis, are there any noticeable differences that you're seeing over the past quarter or two, either geographically or say the split betwee
componenttext: When you're looking at the portfolio in terms of the performance, whether it be on a spread basis, sales performance basis, are there any noticeable differences that you're seeing over the past quarter or two, either geographically or say the split between traditional strip and street retail?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I would have to say, Michael, no.  I would have to say no. I mean the -- I don't mean to sound like a broken record here, but the commonality is the quality of the real estate and that really applies to within each market to all types of uses and all type
componenttext: I would have to say, Michael, no.  I would have to say no. I mean the -- I don't mean to sound like a broken record here, but the commonality is the quality of the real estate and that really applies to within each market to all types of uses and all types of retail uses in that market. By market, California, for us, clearly has been hit the hardest. If you were to look at the limited number of sales reporting that we do get, you'd get pretty comfortable that boy, California is more volatile or has been more volatile, particularly Northern California. And also by the way, seems to be coming back hard now. Washington never went down that much and that state's solid. And Philadelphia has been a flatline kind of market and continues to stay that way for us. But within those markets, on a relative basis, it truly comes down to the property where it's located.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, we've all seen the comps for the public retailers out there in terms of how well they've been doing. Can you give us a little insight in terms of what you're seeing for the smaller tenants, the moms and pops, when you look at your sales
componenttext: And then secondly, we've all seen the comps for the public retailers out there in terms of how well they've been doing. Can you give us a little insight in terms of what you're seeing for the smaller tenants, the moms and pops, when you look at your sales reports and just talk to them?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it fails overall on the small shop tenants, moms and pops probably came down for us 5%, 6% or so on the East Coast, a little bit more than that on the West Coast, over the last 18 months or so. That clearly has seem to stabilize. Now it hasn't stabil
componenttext: Yes, it fails overall on the small shop tenants, moms and pops probably came down for us 5%, 6% or so on the East Coast, a little bit more than that on the West Coast, over the last 18 months or so. That clearly has seem to stabilize. Now it hasn't stabilized for everybody and there has been a shift. If you were a marginal business, a marginal mom-and-pop business, kind of before this started and you've been finding a way to hold on, there's just so long you can hold on. And some of those tenants are not coming back in terms of the sales, and we will continue to see some of those tenants fail. But overall, there has been a new base kind of set. I just looked at the first quarter sales stuff for a small shop and they're not going down anymore. Now the comparisons are not all that hard from first quarter of '09 versus first quarter of '10. But still, there has been a bottoming and the most important psychological thing of that bottoming is even those mom and pops now, who have now gotten comfortable or used to a lower sales level are in larger and larger numbers, not thinking about giving up the shift, but rather how they can start improving and growing again. So I see that as positive right now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010

componenttext: I don't know, Andy, what do you think pretty much from where we are? We'll lose some of the small shop, we'll pick up some but the difference -- the interesting thing with this portfolio always which makes it a little harder to predict in some respect is it's only 18 million square feet. So we lease up a box or two and you start adding 100,000 square feet to the non-vacancy numbers, the occupied numbers and it matters, right? Every point is about 180,000 square feet here. So absent -- we expect a couple of those things to happen, we expect to lose some small shop a little bit along the way, maybe a box or two, we'll end up about where we are we think.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: So if you -- it seems to me that you're fairly full, basically, not quite I guess you could get to 97%. And if it's kind of hard to find acquisitions at this point, the tenants I think, you probably agree going, are going to be looking for more space goin
componenttext: So if you -- it seems to me that you're fairly full, basically, not quite I guess you could get to 97%. And if it's kind of hard to find acquisitions at this point, the tenants I think, you probably agree going, are going to be looking for more space going into 2011 and 2012. It seems though that the urgency around redevelopment should increase, and maybe it is and I'm just not sensing that, but it seems like that's a great avenue that you should really be pressing forward here.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, you're right, Rich. Absolutely. And yes, don't give up on the acquisition so soon. It's so funny, we're all -- and yet you kind of sense it in David's question, maybe in Chris' question, certainly around the company. When we gave guidance that we -- I
componenttext: No, you're right, Rich. Absolutely. And yes, don't give up on the acquisition so soon. It's so funny, we're all -- and yet you kind of sense it in David's question, maybe in Chris' question, certainly around the company. When we gave guidance that we -- I hope to do a $1 billion over the next four years, that's '10, '11, '12, '13. And look, I have no idea whether we'll get to that $1 billion or not. But what I do know is, as Jeff said, there's a palpable difference today from just 90 days ago in terms of what's happening out there. And I guess I am pleading for patience, because I think what's important is that we make sure that we buy the right stuff. We absolutely, as I said to somebody else before, have redevelopment as a critical part and always has been and always will be of our business plan. And we're finding some pretty decent bottoming out, if you will, of the leverage that tenants have. So on all three things, it doesn't mean it's 2007, again, hey, here we go, finding such imagination. But on a relative basis, I think you should be pretty happy with the way this portfolio has performed on all three.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to think on the redevelopment side of things, I mean, you must have some stuff going, some things in place and some of activities that would get us somewhere close to that $75 million, or on track toward that $75 million, maybe by 2012. Is that
componenttext: I'm trying to think on the redevelopment side of things, I mean, you must have some stuff going, some things in place and some of activities that would get us somewhere close to that $75 million, or on track toward that $75 million, maybe by 2012. Is that true or is that too aggressive?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May-05-2010
componenttextpreview: You know what? Take a look at the 8-K. See what you got in there. There's -- you'll see one or two things being added to that, you'll see one or two things coming off that as it goes forward. What you have to remember is in Mid-Pike alone, there is $1 bil
componenttext: You know what? Take a look at the 8-K. See what you got in there. There's -- you'll see one or two things being added to that, you'll see one or two things coming off that as it goes forward. What you have to remember is in Mid-Pike alone, there is $1 billion to spend on Mid-Pike. It won't all be our billion dollars so relax, but there is plenty of money for us to put out. And I'd much rather put it out to places that we really know and underwrite some of these growth. If we can figure out Assembly Square, there's a ton of money that can be put out and how much we do ourselves versus how much we sell-off is very dependent on our level of confidence in achieving certain numbers. So I don't think you should worry all that much about Federal's ability that either: A, use its currency; or B, put money to work. But that is not smooth line. And you'll see a quiet '09, you'll see a quite '10, and you'll probably be on a phone call in a year or two, telling me, "Hey, slow down." But just depend on the market conditions, that's all.
