headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Second Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; and Jeff Berkes. These and other members o
componenttext:
Thank you and good morning. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Second Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood; Dawn Becker; Andy Blocher; and Jeff Berkes. These and other members of our management team are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks.
Our second quarter 2010 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained. 
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but are not limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of second quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. With half of the 2010 year in the books, Federal is performing better than we expected, with reported FFO per share in the second quarter of $0.98, higher than the $0.94 we recorded in the first quarter and also s
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina, and good morning, everyone. With half of the 2010 year in the books, Federal is performing better than we expected, with reported FFO per share in the second quarter of $0.98, higher than the $0.94 we recorded in the first quarter and also slightly ahead of the $0.97 recorded in last year's second quarter.
It really was a fine operating quarter and first half in total for us, with rental income up 3.3% and expenses very much under control. We do see some potential cracks in the armor in the second half of the year, primarily related to tenants who are given up after a couple of years of subsidizing their businesses from other sources and so bad debt expenses could creep up again, but nothing overly significant. In short, we expect overall performance in the second half of the year to mirror or perhaps be slightly better than our very good first half.
In terms of regional performance, our properties in the Washington D.C. Metro Area, which make up about a third of our company, seem to be coming back a bit stronger than other markets, with modestly improving tenant sales and increased demand from retailers being the obvious signs. 
Overall, California remains the weakest performing region for us. Although Santana Row, which saw a double-digit sales hit over the course of the recession, seems to be coming back particularly well and has really solidified itself as the social center of Silicon Valley. We see it in the form higher occupancy in rate at Hotel Valencia. We see it in the form of higher rental rates in the apartments. And we certainly see it in higher foot traffic in retail sales.  
We did begin construction during the quarter on schedule of our 109-unit apartment building at Santana that should be completed next year and stabilize in 2012 at a 7% yield. As we've talked about previously, we may choose to convert those units into condos during the next bull condo market for a strong double-digit IRR. 
In terms of the newly built office of a retail building at Santana, we're not there yet but we are making progress. We signed a strong deal during the quarter with Yard House for a 10,000 square foot restaurant on the hard corner of Stevens Creek in Santana Row. And interior build out is underway for the second floor office tenant with a rent start date of December 1. Still more office leasing to go, but we're very encouraged by what's happening at Santana Row these days. And if you haven't been in our flagship property in a number of years, it might be a good time for a return trip.
Okay. Enough about Santana and let's talk a bit more about leasing for the quarter. 80 comparable deals for over 300,000 square feet at an average rent of $27.62, 4% more than the rent that was replaced on a year-over-year cash basis and 13% more on a straight-line basis over the lease term. While that rollover rate is lower than it's been, we also saw some good news in the detail behind that number. 
While there weren't any significant renewals of old leases with big bumps during the quarter as they were in first, there was also a lot less deal-by-deal deviation than in prior quarters. In other words, there were less deals done at significant decreases than there have been recently. And therefore, we saw more consistency in deal making. While we sure wish that we had some more leverage with retailers to push rents, this is still a solid result and perhaps more predictable. 
Physical occupancy has remained extremely stable at 93% overall and 94% on a same-center basis. And lease percentage is about 100 basis points better than that. Again, I wouldn't expect to see much of a change for the balance of the year.
Okay. Let's talk about a couple more areas before turning it over to Andy. Acquisition prospects and Assembly Square, which is soon to be called Assembly Row. Well as you know by now, we certainly haven't yet found lots of big impactful acquisition values out there that will change the course of Federal Realty. But we have quietly put together a string of real estate investments that have either closed or are about to close the total of about $60 million that’ll contribute about a 7% return initially and create significant value over the years. 
The first is our $18 million acquisition of two great buildings on Newbury Street in Boston that hopefully represent our first of many investments on that great shopping street. Significant upside is expected by leasing up the office space in the upper floors of the two buildings we bought. 
Second is our contract to buy the former Mervyn's store that has shadow anchored our strong-performing Escondido shopping center in the San Diego suburb. The box should be retained with a new Dick's and Ross stores. We’re pretty far along on the leases. In fact, I think Dick's is a done deal, and Ross is close. And if it's not them, it’ll be somebody else. They'll not only increase the yield of the shopping center but will also arguably lower the cap rate of the entire center. 
Third is our acquisition of Huntington Square Shopping Center on Long Island for $18 million that will further build on Federal's already strong regional presence; retail presence that includes Huntington Shopping Center, Greenlawns Plaza, Melville Mall and Hauppauge Shopping Center. Huntington Square includes tenants like Dress Barn, Barnes & Noble and Lane Bryant and is shadow anchored by Sears. The property was renovated in 2007, was bought at a strong yield and has additional lease upside.
Finally, we negotiated a buyout of the land under a portion of our extremely successful Bethesda Row project for about $10 million. The land is on Bethesda Avenue. And it's home to tenants like Apple, Dunkin' Donuts and local restaurants and by owning the fee, further enhances Bethesda's value in addition to producing a strong FFO portfolio. 
We continue to search for a great addition to this portfolio including much larger deals. But I think you'd agree that the $60 million enumerated above is much more likely to be long-term accretive to value than some of the similarly sized shopping center acquisitions that we've seen in the marketplace. 
And finally, a word about Assembly Row. Our mixed-use opportunity in Somerville, Mass [Massachusetts] just outside of Boston. As those of you who follow us know, I've been very cautious about making any promises concerning our ability to deliver a large viable development here given the state of the economy, given our growing cost basis and given the numerous government hurdles regarding the proposed T-Stop at the site. 
Be assured that I'm still very cautious and would really prefer that when valuing Federal Realty, that you not ascribe incremental value to Assembly. In fact, without a T-Stop and the public financing that we're counting on, it's unlikely that we'd be able to recover our existing investments. 
Now having said that, this past three or four months have seen a tangible increase in interest in the site from retailers that we talk to, from potential office tenants and most significantly, from residential developers. Several months ago, we asked for bids on the first 400 residential units in the project in an RFP process that yielded significant interest in the site from some of the best residential developers in the country. In the end, we selected AvalonBay to negotiate with, and we have a handshake deal with them to buy the residential rights for the first phase. Hopefully, we can get to a signed contract. 
Having a strong a name as Avalon compete aggressively for this site in their own backyard really validates Assembly Row as a residential destination and when combined with Federal Realty's retail and mixed-use expertise, really should be viewed as a very positive step. Still lots of hurdles to cross, but we're thrilled to be working with Bryce Blair  on this team at Assembly.
That's all I’ve got for my prepared remarks this morning. Now let me turn it over to Andy. And I look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Federal Realty produced another very solid consistent quarter despite the continuing tough economic environment. Lease rollovers were positive, though down from the exceptional results last quarter. Occupancy remai
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good morning, everyone. Federal Realty produced another very solid consistent quarter despite the continuing tough economic environment. Lease rollovers were positive, though down from the exceptional results last quarter. Occupancy remains flat. And as a result, our portfolio again produced positive same-center growth. This consistent performance throughout the economic downturn, along with our very solid balance sheet, allowed us to increase our dividend again this year, marking the 43rd consecutive year of increased annual dividends.
Same-center property operating income growth for the quarter was 3.4% including redevelopments. This growth was driven by the 3.3% growth in rental income that Don discussed in his remarks, which includes an increase in minimum rent, supplemented with a boost in ancillary income and canned true-ups throughout the portfolio. 
Going forward, we expect same-center property operating income including redevelopments to come in at the top of our previous guidance of 1% to 1½% on the positive side. This certainly implies lower same-center growth in the second half of the year than we've reported in both the first and second quarters. 
In particular, third quarter same-center growth will be impacted by the following items: first, a continued decrease in lease terms fees, as we accelerated the remaining lease term fee for the Home Depot termination at Flourtown into the first quarter of this year. I think this is about $1 million in the hole on a comparable basis.  
Second, an expected increase in demolition expenses in the third quarter to prepare for new major tenants, including Neiman Marcus Last Call at Congressional Plaza, Nordstrom Rack at Friendship Center, Dick's at Governor Plaza and others. 
And finally, bad debt to be higher than last year, as we reported less than $1 million in the third quarter of '09, one of the lowest levels we've seen since the downturn in the economy. Items such as these can cause same-center growth to vary quarter-to-quarter. Accordingly, we continue to believe the full year result is an appropriate way to view this metric. 
With respect to the dividend, recall that a year ago, many REITs decided to cut, suspend or pay the dividend in stock. Bucking that trend, Federal Realty is one of the very few REITs that not only continued to pay that dividend in cash, but also increased the dividend based on our expectation of consistent solid performance from our portfolio of high-quality intel of retail assets. 
Our decision to increase the dividend in each of the past two years was based on continued growth in taxable income, strong free cash flow after dividend payments and very solid dividend and coverage ratios. While you all know that this dividend record ranks first amongst all REITs, a record of dividend achievement ranks 22nd amongst all publicly traded companies in the U.S., that's over 11,000 of them, putting us in the elite company of Procter & Gamble, 3M, Coca-Cola, Colgate-Palmolive, Johnson & Johnson, Tootsie Roll Industries, Altria and Hormel Foods. We continue to believe that increasing cash dividend is part of our contract with investors and hope that we'll be talking about our 44th consecutive year 12 months from now. 
Our balance sheet remains in great shape. And the capital markets remain cooperative, with all-in debt costs remaining at or near the recent lows and equity prices remaining relatively attractive. As a result, we continue to be in enviable position to fund the right acquisitions both on a short-term and on a longer-term basis. At the quarter end, we had the full $300 million of credit facility capacity at our disposal. The one acquisition we've closed so far this year, Newbury Street in Boston, was funded with free cash flow.
Our balance sheet ratios continue to support our strong Baa1, BBB+ rating with a couple of key statistics. We have no debt maturities in 2010 and only $112 million coming due in 2011. Debt-to-book value of 41%, remember that, that book value reflects our very low historic cost basis. Debt-to-total market capitalization of 28%, fixed charge coverage above 3x and debtor preferred to annualized EBITDA of 5x. 
As for guidance, we now have a bit more clarity with the solid six months of operating performance behind us and have increased the lower end of our guidance by $0.02 to a range of $3.84 to $3.89 per diluted share, buoyed by our upward revision to same-store property operating income growth including redevelopments that I discussed earlier. 
Just to be clear, the increase in guidance comes despite some earnings dilution in 2010 from the four acquisitions we announced. As we've discussed for a number of quarters, we must now expense the related acquisition deal costs rather than capitalizing them into our basis. And these costs, plus associated borrowing costs, are greater than the partial year property operating income contribution of the acquisitions.
We're really pleased with the solid and consistent results that our portfolio continues to produce over this difficult economic time. With that, I'd now be happy to turn the call over to you for your questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Christy McElroy from UBS.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you can provide some more detail on the economics of the Taurus JV, the genesis of the formation of the partnership. And I would think that you would want more control in terms of the management, operations and leasing in a JV. Is it bec
componenttext: Just wondering if you can provide some more detail on the economics of the Taurus JV, the genesis of the formation of the partnership. And I would think that you would want more control in terms of the management, operations and leasing in a JV. Is it because the upside is mostly from the office leasing? And does that control pertain to just the two assets that you already bought or any future acquisitions of the TV?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me tell you how we got into the deal first and why we set it up the way we did. We know the folks at Taurus real well. They’re the folks we've acquired Assembly Square from several years ago. We've maintained a great relationship with them, an
componenttext: Sure. Let me tell you how we got into the deal first and why we set it up the way we did. We know the folks at Taurus real well. They’re the folks we've acquired Assembly Square from several years ago. We've maintained a great relationship with them, and they've been a very active investor all over the world, quite frankly, for the last several years. A couple years ago, they formed a partnership or joint venture with the company that's headquartered in Back Bay, Boston called Urban Meritage. And they've developed with Urban Meritage a very nice operating platform to not only acquire but also to redevelop, manage and lease the types of buildings you'd see in Back Bay, Boston. I think together, Taurus and Urban Meritage have acquired close to 20 buildings in Back Bay now over the last three, four years. So they've got a real well developed and strong operating platform. And we thought it made sense to invest along with them. The deal set up, where we put in 85% of the equity and they put in 15%, target leverage on the joint venture's 50% to 60%. And then through the joint venture documents, we have a significant amount of control and input on everything that's important, acquisitions and financing, obviously, but also, we have an annual business plan process with each of the buildings we acquire that effectively gives us control over leasing decisions and redevelopment decisions as well. So again we're very, very happy to have them as a partner. I think they've set up a fabulous platform and I think that we have appropriate controls given our level of investment in the JV.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Given the platform that they've established, is it possible that they might partner with you in some way on the Assembly Row development?
componenttext: Given the platform that they've established, is it possible that they might partner with you in some way on the Assembly Row development?

componenttext: No, that's really not their bailiwick, if you will.

componenttext: And then just with regard to AvalonBay developing the apartments at Assembly Row, how would that deal be structured from your perspective? And would they be ground leasing the land?

componenttextpreview: Yes, effectively, they would. They would ground lease it from us. They would do the building, we'd buy back the retail shell underneath. And that deal is, obviously, it's is not done yet. And we're working toward getting it done. But having them there wou
componenttext: Yes, effectively, they would. They would ground lease it from us. They would do the building, we'd buy back the retail shell underneath. And that deal is, obviously, it's is not done yet. And we're working toward getting it done. But having them there would be great.

componenttext: And then just lastly, are you assuming any debt associated with the assets that you’ve bought and have under contract?

componenttext: No, I don't think so. On that group of assets...

componenttext: No, that would be all cash.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Morgan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Sticking with the Newbury Street, I mean how specific is that opportunity to kind of what you came across there? Or are you looking at other sort of urban mixed-use acquisitions? Is it really just kind of what you saw at Newbury and how the opportunity ca
componenttext: Sticking with the Newbury Street, I mean how specific is that opportunity to kind of what you came across there? Or are you looking at other sort of urban mixed-use acquisitions? Is it really just kind of what you saw at Newbury and how the opportunity came about?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is, Paul. I mean look, there has been no period where it's been tougher to try to find ways to deploy capital where we could see a path to creating real value. And I think some of the stuff that's happening on the basic grocery-anchored stuff that
componenttext: Yes, it is, Paul. I mean look, there has been no period where it's been tougher to try to find ways to deploy capital where we could see a path to creating real value. And I think some of the stuff that's happening on the basic grocery-anchored stuff that we've been seeing lately has made it real difficult to be able to see a path. I think there's a lot of anchor boxes in there or small anchors in there that are over market. And we see some of those things rolling down in the future, and other people are willing to pay up for that; we’re not. So kind of by nature of what's happening in that sector, we're looking for high-quality retail and high-quality retail real estate primarily. And the mixed-use stuff in some of the urban areas, obviously, we've done a bunch of it before. So we kind of know our way around there. And when the Newbury Street opportunity came up, we kind of jumped on it. We did that for a couple of reasons. Jeff enumerate them. First of all, the fact that we had the previous relationships with these guys is big. I mean, we knew it was a very, very good transaction to work out Assembly Square a few years back with them. We know how they deal, and that was really positive. Secondly, Boston is a big market for us now. And again, I don't know whether Assembly ultimately makes or doesn't make. But even without that, we have a full service office up there so Newbury was strong. It does look a little bit to me like the deal that we cut 15 years ago or so on Third Street Promenade in Santa Monica, where we had a local partner, we JV-ed with them. We've made a lot of money out there and we're hoping to replicate that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Don, you alluded to kind of bad debt and some small shops that just weren't able to make it. Could you give a little more color to that? Is that geographically concentrated or kind of industry concentrated? And is it saying anything about kind o
componenttext: And then, Don, you alluded to kind of bad debt and some small shops that just weren't able to make it. Could you give a little more color to that? Is that geographically concentrated or kind of industry concentrated? And is it saying anything about kind of the state of the recovery? Or is this just folks who really just weren't able -- got hit so bad from the recession that they're just not able to keep going?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit of both, Paul. I mean, look, in our business whether we like it or not it, one of the eventualities is a lot of tenants are not going to make it. What has happened over the past couple of years is basically an acceleration of that, and p
componenttext: It's a little bit of both, Paul. I mean, look, in our business whether we like it or not it, one of the eventualities is a lot of tenants are not going to make it. What has happened over the past couple of years is basically an acceleration of that, and particularly in the better properties, people finding a way to be able to finance that and to work through that period of time. That is still the case. There are just some that aren't going to be able to. So I don't really see it as a special red flag or red light in any way, shape or form that way. I mean overall, we wouldn't be able to kind of give guidance towards the earnings we're talking about, toward the occupancy we’re talking about if we did see it as a big problem. But it is real. The fact of the matter is, if you've been operating with significantly lower sales over the past couple of years and you’ve borrowed from all kinds of non-traditional sources to keep it going, at some point, if those sales don't come back, you say, the bank's closed. And we are absolutely seeing a little bit of that, nothing significantly, though.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about this a little bit, and maybe Jeff could comment on the quality. If there's any change in sort of the quality of the investment opportunities that you're working on now versus earlier in the year. Obviously, pricing is competitive, but jus
componenttext: You talked about this a little bit, and maybe Jeff could comment on the quality. If there's any change in sort of the quality of the investment opportunities that you're working on now versus earlier in the year. Obviously, pricing is competitive, but just in kind of the maybe the volume and quality of the potential acquisitions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Paul. And I think as we've discussed for several quarters now, we've expected to see and are seeing more properties come to market and more transactions close and more properties be put under contract. So the market is getting more active, and
componenttext: Yes, sure, Paul. And I think as we've discussed for several quarters now, we've expected to see and are seeing more properties come to market and more transactions close and more properties be put under contract. So the market is getting more active, and we are starting to see some stuff that is more interesting to us than what we've seen over the last several quarters. Most of the product that's come to the market over the last several quarters, we just really haven't been that interested in because as Don said earlier, there's probably downward pressure on NOI because a lot of the deals that have been brought to market had junior anchors that were leased at the peak of the market or a lot of small shop space that was leased at the peak of the market. And we really don't want to buy assets where we're going to be swimming upstream against declining our flat NOI going forward. We want to buy stuff that medium to long term is going to add value to the company, and we are finally starting to see some of that product come to market. Now it's ridiculously competitive.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I want to what Jeff just said is, he’s absolutely right. I mean, that the product choices seem to be better. The other side of the product choices is the money supply. And it is so strong that frankly the underwriting that some folks are
componenttext: The only thing I want to what Jeff just said is, he’s absolutely right. I mean, that the product choices seem to be better. The other side of the product choices is the money supply. And it is so strong that frankly the underwriting that some folks are doing, we cannot get our head behind. And if they're willing to underwrite things that we just can't see, they're going to win. So that's the deal.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: A lot of people are banking on some future rent growth in order to make numbers work. And there's not a ton of evidence of that right now.
componenttext: A lot of people are banking on some future rent growth in order to make numbers work. And there's not a ton of evidence of that right now.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on just a little more color on the urban retail. Just obviously some of your peers have done that. Maybe it was just timing, the point of a cycle that they got into it and expectations. So want to know, does this mean other market
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on just a little more color on the urban retail. Just obviously some of your peers have done that. Maybe it was just timing, the point of a cycle that they got into it and expectations. So want to know, does this mean other markets like SoHo here in New York and other areas like that are opportunities for you? And to make this successful, does it mean that you can have the ability to cluster and have contiguous properties? Or as long as it's a big enough shopping district like a Newbury Street, there's opportunity to buy individual stores up and down the street, then that makes it attractive to you guys?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Alex, let me put this in context because we are not going to go out and buy single buildings on the best streets in America. We've been down that road a while ago when we were a much smaller company and that doesn't make sense. We need to make signi
componenttext: Well, Alex, let me put this in context because we are not going to go out and buy single buildings on the best streets in America. We've been down that road a while ago when we were a much smaller company and that doesn't make sense. We need to make significant investments. And so to the extent -- and Newbury's a great example. Buying those two buildings is fine. But I will tell you, if we are unable to execute under this venture and buy significantly more real estate in and around the area, then we'll sell those two buildings in a few years because we're not going to own a small amount of retail on any street, SoHo, Newbury Street, Third Street Promenade, anywhere. We've got to be able to cluster it to have it make sense to us. So I don't want you to think that this is a new kind of initiative of the firm. It's not. We are very much looking for great quality real estate that we can add value on. This particular case, if it were just these two buildings, there weren't opportunities for more, we wouldn't do it. And so it's got to be significant. I hope that helps.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question just goes to the Avalon deal and just your view of what you would do in-house for apartments versus what you would sell off or have another party do. Is it a matter of opportunities where there's a potential to condo the deal
componenttext: And then the second question just goes to the Avalon deal and just your view of what you would do in-house for apartments versus what you would sell off or have another party do. Is it a matter of opportunities where there's a potential to condo the deal at some later point, those are the types of deals that you would keep in-house? And if it is just purely rental, you would get a third party involved? How should we think about that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you should think about it kind of the way we've looked at other long-term projects that we build over time. Think of Bethesda Row that's been built over 15 years. If there is a great Assembly Row destination, it's a 10-year build out. It's a long
componenttext: I think you should think about it kind of the way we've looked at other long-term projects that we build over time. Think of Bethesda Row that's been built over 15 years. If there is a great Assembly Row destination, it's a 10-year build out. It's a long period of time as we go forward. The idea of starting out in an area that we don't know nearly as well and that is residential in a new market that way is not appealing to us. And I think Avalon will do a better job than we can do. As we go further, we very well may sell the whole thing to Avalon and let them do every bit of it, or we may do some of it ourselves or some other third party at the time. We're not going to plan out the entire 10-year progress until we see what happens along the way. And having said all that, I can tell you that the single biggest thing that I worry about the most is the government funding. Because the world is changing like crazy and to the extent they don't get that T-Stop funded or we don't get the I-Cubed’s money and the other stuff that we're looking at, going to be real hard to make any numbers work there. And we're not going to build it to make it pretty, so it's going to all have to work.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally, Andy, in the third quarter, did you comment on what the deal costs are? And if there's anything else like any debt amortization or anything else that will be sort of onetime-ish the third quarter?
componenttext: And just finally, Andy, in the third quarter, did you comment on what the deal costs are? And if there's anything else like any debt amortization or anything else that will be sort of onetime-ish the third quarter?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean nothing specific in the third quarter. Obviously, we got the one deal that we recently closed. We’ve got others in the process. There's nothing super unusual. The real point to note is as I read through the research, I see everybody saying,
componenttext: No, I mean nothing specific in the third quarter. Obviously, we got the one deal that we recently closed. We’ve got others in the process. There's nothing super unusual. The real point to note is as I read through the research, I see everybody saying, “Oh, they’re doing acquisitions and the acquisitions are going to be accretive,” you've got a couple of different deals. You've got the Bethesda deal that doesn't close until like the last business day of the year, so no real contribution. You've got the Huntington deal, where you're going to get some positive contribution but need to net it against acquisition expenses and the interest area. So it really is just to kind of make the point that based on the timing of when these things are being bought, don't expect big accretion in 2010 but nothing super unusual.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, you just touched on this a second ago but I do think it was about the time that you joined Federal that the company was finishing up embarking on the street retail acquisition. There are opportunities around the country. I think you even were involve
componenttext: Don, you just touched on this a second ago but I do think it was about the time that you joined Federal that the company was finishing up embarking on the street retail acquisition. There are opportunities around the country. I think you even were involved in winding that down. I guess, why did or didn't that work out last time? Is the difference this time around just that you're just going to concentrate it more?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: It's interesting, Jeff, it's a really good question. First of all, the definition of why didn't it work out last time, it did work out in terms of making money for Federal Realty. It did not work out in terms of being impactful enough to matter and it too
componenttext: It's interesting, Jeff, it's a really good question. First of all, the definition of why didn't it work out last time, it did work out in terms of making money for Federal Realty. It did not work out in terms of being impactful enough to matter and it took a whole bunch of management time. It takes the same amount of management time to manage a $60 million shopping center, as it does a $10 million or $12 million building in a lot of respects. And so that's what didn't make sense, which is why you're not going to find us entering new markets. We used to own something in Evanston, Illinois. We used to own something in Westfield, New Jersey. We used to own a lot of those small buildings that were scattered all around the country. We're not going to do that. It doesn't make any sense for the size company we are. That's why I say this is a unique opportunity with a unique group of people to give us a strong presence on a street and in a particular area. And if we can do that, great. And if we can't, we'll probably never talk about it again because we’ll sell it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then actually specific, to Back Bay, I mean is it your thinking that this joint venture with Taurus will target the assets that are currently owned by Urban Meritage? Or are you really just thinking beyond those assets? Because I think they own 10 to
componenttext: And then actually specific, to Back Bay, I mean is it your thinking that this joint venture with Taurus will target the assets that are currently owned by Urban Meritage? Or are you really just thinking beyond those assets? Because I think they own 10 to 20 commercial and then commercial and residential assets currently.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we'd love to own those. I mean the existing stuff, the new stuff, we'd love to be able to do it. Is there a deal? Can we make it? Who knows? But no, everything's on the table.
componenttext: No, we'd love to own those. I mean the existing stuff, the new stuff, we'd love to be able to do it. Is there a deal? Can we make it? Who knows? But no, everything's on the table.

componenttextpreview: Are you limiting yourself to Newbury Street exclusively? Or just I should say Newbury Street retail exclusively?
componenttext: Are you limiting yourself to Newbury Street exclusively? Or just I should say Newbury Street retail exclusively?

componenttextpreview: No, the Back Bay area. So it could be Boylston, it could be a few blocks one way or the other, but that basic area.
componenttext: No, the Back Bay area. So it could be Boylston, it could be a few blocks one way or the other, but that basic area.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And are you willing to -- maybe it's not your focus, but are you willing to take on more residential or office space buildings as well? Or how do you think of that?
componenttext: And are you willing to -- maybe it's not your focus, but are you willing to take on more residential or office space buildings as well? Or how do you think of that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, yes. One of my favorite buildings that we own is in Bethesda Row, is the project that we did last year with 180 or so apartment units over great retail. To the extent it's integrated and it's stable, we're happy to do it. But it depends on th
componenttext: Yes, I mean, yes. One of my favorite buildings that we own is in Bethesda Row, is the project that we did last year with 180 or so apartment units over great retail. To the extent it's integrated and it's stable, we're happy to do it. But it depends on the quality of the income statement.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a last question. AvalonBay at Assembly Row, help us think about the ground lease concept that you mentioned. I mean, do you have a sense of maybe roughly where you think multi-family development yields would pencil on that site? Or can you at lea
componenttext: And just a last question. AvalonBay at Assembly Row, help us think about the ground lease concept that you mentioned. I mean, do you have a sense of maybe roughly where you think multi-family development yields would pencil on that site? Or can you at least give us a rough estimate maybe on the timing of the construction, the start or completion?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I do have a rough idea and no, I can't tell you. Listen, we're in the early stages of negotiations here with these guys. Let us get through it at all, and then we'll talk about it once there’s a done deal. Sorry to be that vague, but I need to be.
componenttext: I do have a rough idea and no, I can't tell you. Listen, we're in the early stages of negotiations here with these guys. Let us get through it at all, and then we'll talk about it once there’s a done deal. Sorry to be that vague, but I need to be.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jay Habermann with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jay Habermann with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, you mentioned D.C. is performing well. Obviously, it's leading a bit here in the recovery. Can you give us just some sense of what you're seeing in terms of the increases, I guess, in maybe asking rents? Or is it really the sales have just ticked up
componenttext: Don, you mentioned D.C. is performing well. Obviously, it's leading a bit here in the recovery. Can you give us just some sense of what you're seeing in terms of the increases, I guess, in maybe asking rents? Or is it really the sales have just ticked up and you expect rents to sort of follow?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a little bit of both. I mean and again, I think I've said this in the past, our sales population is small so you can't get too much out of it. But period-over-period, our sales in the D.C. market are up 3%, 4%, 5%, something like that pretty con
componenttext: Yes, it's a little bit of both. I mean and again, I think I've said this in the past, our sales population is small so you can't get too much out of it. But period-over-period, our sales in the D.C. market are up 3%, 4%, 5%, something like that pretty consistently. And what I was trying to say in my prepared remarks was the word consistency is -- I haven't used the word consistency a lot about anything in the past couple of years. And while we're not going to be able to push rents dramatically overall in the portfolio, we're also not -- there are just not that many occasions where we're dropping a lot either. So the range is getting tighter, Jay, and the best example I can give is we just did a deal with Neiman Marcus' Last Call Studio concept. It's a new concept for them. This, I think – and Chris is here, he can tell me -- I think this is the only one they're doing in the Washington D.C. Metropolitan area. And it's at Congressional. It's right here. We just did Nordstrom Rack, back filling, I think the Linens 'n Things space that was down in Friendship place. All are good rents, these are good deals. These are not subsidized deals. These are good, strong retailers with strong sales. So that's what I'm seeing more in this region than in other places, Jay. I don't know if that's helpful.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess just back to the question on acquisitions. As you look at sort of As versus Bs or even properties that might need some redevelopment and again, setting aside the urban properties, are you seeing any difference in terms of the returns that you
componenttext: And I guess just back to the question on acquisitions. As you look at sort of As versus Bs or even properties that might need some redevelopment and again, setting aside the urban properties, are you seeing any difference in terms of the returns that you can achieve or perhaps more of that product, properties that might need some redevelopment or your expertise might fit in well?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jay. We're seeing more of the type of assets we want to buy come to market or owners that own those properties get a little bit more engaged in a sale transaction.
componenttext: Yes, Jay. We're seeing more of the type of assets we want to buy come to market or owners that own those properties get a little bit more engaged in a sale transaction.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Jay, the thing that add to it, though, and it gets back to the same price conversation, yes, I think we’re pretty good redevelopers. But we're not going to pay for the benefits for the redevelopment as though they’re already done at the acquisition or
componenttext: Jay, the thing that add to it, though, and it gets back to the same price conversation, yes, I think we’re pretty good redevelopers. But we're not going to pay for the benefits for the redevelopment as though they’re already done at the acquisition or there's no juice left. And seems like some people will. So to the extent those deals are going for prices that basically assume the redevelopment is completed, there's really not much point in us competing there. And we are still seeing a lot of that stuff, which is why you’re not -- it does come down to price. You're not seeing a lot of acquisition activity in that type of product for us. I hope that changes. But so far, it hasn't.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with ISI Group.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa with ISI Group.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: At the risk of beating a dead horse on the Boston project, are there any contingencies that might be in a transaction with Avalon i.e. if a T-Stop doesn't get built, does the deal sort of come undone? Or are there kind of hurdles in there? I mean, I'm jus
componenttext: At the risk of beating a dead horse on the Boston project, are there any contingencies that might be in a transaction with Avalon i.e. if a T-Stop doesn't get built, does the deal sort of come undone? Or are there kind of hurdles in there? I mean, I'm just trying to understand how the T-Stop might impact or not impact that project.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: It's really important. Yes, there are all kinds of contingencies. We may never get to a deal with Avalon, and that's kind of my prepared remarks. Yes, there’s tons of contingencies and the T-Stop is critical to making at least to the initial phases, cer
componenttext: It's really important. Yes, there are all kinds of contingencies. We may never get to a deal with Avalon, and that's kind of my prepared remarks. Yes, there’s tons of contingencies and the T-Stop is critical to making at least to the initial phases, certainly of making the site a site where people can access it easily and work there and live there and shop there. So to the extent there is no T, I'm not sure we would -- forget about Avalon’s contingency. I'm not sure we would want to move forward there. So I know you probably think I sandbag a lot and stuff, but those preliminary comments about not putting value into that right now, I really mean because on Monday, I feel great about the project. On Tuesday, I get some bad news. On Wednesday, I feel great again and that's kind of the nature of this thing. But the point I was trying to bring up is when a company like Avalon really wants to do residential units there and they were not the only ones and they were not the only ones of really great reputation and quality there, I don't think that can be over emphasized enough because that really does say that people who are very, very familiar with the area, with the region and with the site think that this could be a great spot. So that's kind of where I’d take it. I still would put value on it, Steve.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Secondly, could you just maybe give a little more color -- I'm just trying to understand kind of on the rent spreads, I know you said there's been consistency and sounds like you're maybe even thinking there's going to be some fallout in the second half o
componenttext: Secondly, could you just maybe give a little more color -- I'm just trying to understand kind of on the rent spreads, I know you said there's been consistency and sounds like you're maybe even thinking there's going to be some fallout in the second half of the year. But types of tenants or size of tenants, national versus mom and pop. I mean is it really still of the kind of mom-and-pop local tenant where you're seeing the most distress and issues?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. I tell you, I think it's pretty much across the board. I know I've said that consistently and I know that's different than what other folks say, but in our 18 million square feet, I really don't have a profile of the failing tenants or so. Chr
componenttext: Not really. I tell you, I think it's pretty much across the board. I know I've said that consistently and I know that's different than what other folks say, but in our 18 million square feet, I really don't have a profile of the failing tenants or so. Chris Weilminster's here and he does it every day. Chris, do you have any take on this?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you’re right, Don. I don't think we're seeing any trends that would say this is a category that's absolutely disappearing. We are just seeing tenants that have run out of capital to stay in business, and that varies across the board. And so I do
componenttext: I think you’re right, Don. I don't think we're seeing any trends that would say this is a category that's absolutely disappearing. We are just seeing tenants that have run out of capital to stay in business, and that varies across the board. And so I don't think there's really much more to be said other than what Don's remarks are. I think it's pretty simple that way.

componenttext: On Huntington Square, is there a source of REIT merchandising there, at the center at all? Or what kind of federal expertise is going to be put upon that center?

componenttext: Hopefully someday, getting control of the Sears, but not a lot, Craig, to get started. I mean look, what we bought there was yield for now. It has been redone to the extent that it can be. So for the next couple of years, nothing. It is good quality income stream coming in. We did it, Craig, because it's right down the road from a lot of other stuff that we own on Long Island. And to the extent that Sears becomes ours in time, there's a lot of money to make there. It's a great location. But in terms of what we can underwrite, and what we can kind of point you to as to where we'd at a lot value on the site as it is, we can't. Good deals, great real estate, strong income statement.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just since there's a Barnes & Noble there, I'm just wondering in terms of your leasing going forward, how are you going to be approaching the bookstore environment just given the news out on Barnes & Noble and obviously, Borders issues?
componenttext: I guess, just since there's a Barnes & Noble there, I'm just wondering in terms of your leasing going forward, how are you going to be approaching the bookstore environment just given the news out on Barnes & Noble and obviously, Borders issues?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: With a lot of caution. I mean, we're certainly not going to be kind of rolling over on lease requests from them. We're almost always at every Barnes & Noble and every Borders and every bookstore looking real hard to make sure we've got all our options, in
componenttext: With a lot of caution. I mean, we're certainly not going to be kind of rolling over on lease requests from them. We're almost always at every Barnes & Noble and every Borders and every bookstore looking real hard to make sure we've got all our options, including what replacement tenants. It's a tough business as you know to be very, very bullish on in the future. They've been a great tenant for us, they'll continue to be for a period of time but the reality is such that if this one at Huntington Square, for example, were well over market, we probably wouldn't have done it. It's not. It's a reasonable rent for the space and we know we could replace it and probably improve on it a bit. So it's certainly not a category that we're good to be investing significant TIs and to get deals done going forward.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, on the Boston stuff, you guys used to do street retail as you pointed out. And you had in your supplemental as a separate category. And you took out that moniker because presumably, you weren't getting credit for it as you mentioned. And Kimco has so
componenttext: Don, on the Boston stuff, you guys used to do street retail as you pointed out. And you had in your supplemental as a separate category. And you took out that moniker because presumably, you weren't getting credit for it as you mentioned. And Kimco has some $200 million of this stuff, and they certainly don't get credit for it. How big do you have to get this business do you think, before you get credit from investors?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: It's not a business. Rich, don't look at this that way. The one thing that -- I guess, Donnelly asked earlier, what didn't work about it in the past. One of the things that didn't work about it was by calling it a separate business. It's not a separate bu
componenttext: It's not a business. Rich, don't look at this that way. The one thing that -- I guess, Donnelly asked earlier, what didn't work about it in the past. One of the things that didn't work about it was by calling it a separate business. It's not a separate business. It is managing a high-income retail income stream, and that's all it is. We'll never break it out. If I had my way, it’ll never be broken -- because it doesn't matter. I mean we're selling a high-quality income stream. And what I was trying to say was on a particular street or in a particular area, we need to have a critical mass so that it makes sense to manage it and run it. So if instead of a grocery-anchored shopping center or a power center, there is a street retail center, which is kind of like what we have on Third Street Promenade, fantastic. But breaking it out and creating a separate business, it doesn't work that way and it won't for us. I hope that helps. That's important.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: My concern, I guess, is that Kimco had the same stream of income. And it never really seemed to generate the excitement for, like you've pointed out, the work that you have to put into it.
componenttext: My concern, I guess, is that Kimco had the same stream of income. And it never really seemed to generate the excitement for, like you've pointed out, the work that you have to put into it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: The excitement, no, Rich. The excitement is when you see Third Street Promenade's NOI going from where it was in 1995 to where it is in 2010. That's all the excitement anybody really cares about.
componenttext: The excitement, no, Rich. The excitement is when you see Third Street Promenade's NOI going from where it was in 1995 to where it is in 2010. That's all the excitement anybody really cares about.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And that is good excitement, I agree with that.
componenttext: And that is good excitement, I agree with that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And by the way, whether that happens on Third Street Promenade or whether it happens at Dedham Plaza in Dedham, Massachusetts, you guys don't care. You just want it to happen. Us too. So it's a matter of buying the right income stream. It's not a matter o
componenttext: And by the way, whether that happens on Third Street Promenade or whether it happens at Dedham Plaza in Dedham, Massachusetts, you guys don't care. You just want it to happen. Us too. So it's a matter of buying the right income stream. It's not a matter of getting into the Street Retail business. I hope that's really clear.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, it kind of gets back to something that we've been saying for a long time, which is what we are. I think that people kind of pigeonhole us as the shopping center company. But the reality is we are a high-quality retail company that has everything x e
componenttext: Rich, it kind of gets back to something that we've been saying for a long time, which is what we are. I think that people kind of pigeonhole us as the shopping center company. But the reality is we are a high-quality retail company that has everything x enclosed malls. We've got great demonstrations of every type of retail property type outside of the mall category. And I think it's that stream of increasing revenues, which is why people pay the multiple.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the redevelopment front, I remember last quarter you were talking maybe an increase in the size of the redevelopments inside your portfolio as opposed to buying something for redevelopment. Do you still see -- obviously, you have Assembly Row
componenttext: And then on the redevelopment front, I remember last quarter you were talking maybe an increase in the size of the redevelopments inside your portfolio as opposed to buying something for redevelopment. Do you still see -- obviously, you have Assembly Row adding to that. But do you still see more redevelopment starting over the next few quarters?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I mean, Dawn, what do you think?
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I mean, Dawn, what do you think?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, there are definitely some that are in the planning stages and a lot them are driven by the marriage of what we see at the property with the leasing potential, and with some of that activity picking up and particularly with the retailers who are
componenttext: Yes, Rich, there are definitely some that are in the planning stages and a lot them are driven by the marriage of what we see at the property with the leasing potential, and with some of that activity picking up and particularly with the retailers who are now going back and focusing a lot heavier on location as opposed to fitting traditional prototypes of how they want to roll their stores out, we're seeing some opportunities that we're exploring that I'm hoping that you'll see a couple more get added in the next quarter or two.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: And then you guys don't talk as much about this, but we hear it from others. Do you see this notion that the retailers can't find enough space for the store openings they want over the next couple of years? I mean, it's a great notion if it's true.
componenttext: And then you guys don't talk as much about this, but we hear it from others. Do you see this notion that the retailers can't find enough space for the store openings they want over the next couple of years? I mean, it's a great notion if it's true.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: It is true. The question that has to be asked is what are the criteria that they're looking for and where do they want to open. And certainly, in the areas that they really want to open, it's hard to find. And that has always been the case. And the only t
componenttext: It is true. The question that has to be asked is what are the criteria that they're looking for and where do they want to open. And certainly, in the areas that they really want to open, it's hard to find. And that has always been the case. And the only thing that really changed when we looked at the '05, '06, '07 period and everything else is their definition of where they wanted to open was dramatically relaxed and expanded. Well now, it's tight again. And you say we don't talk about it, but frankly, we always talk about it. That's the benefit of location, and that's the benefit of the overall demand that we have. And so I definitely think there's something to it. I just think what you have to be careful of is making sure that you understand what the retailers' definition of places that they want to expand in is clear, because that hasn't been.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going back to acquisitions really quick, when you look at your long-term goal of putting $1 billion of capital to work through acquisitions, what are your thoughts on being able to achieve this goal given the current competition in the market today?
componenttext: Just going back to acquisitions really quick, when you look at your long-term goal of putting $1 billion of capital to work through acquisitions, what are your thoughts on being able to achieve this goal given the current competition in the market today?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: This is going to be either truly a "yes" or "no" answer. I think when Jeff says that there's a lot more product that we're interested in, that's very encouraging. And a lot of that stuff’s bigger. And to the extent -- then comes my part to answer. Well,
componenttext: This is going to be either truly a "yes" or "no" answer. I think when Jeff says that there's a lot more product that we're interested in, that's very encouraging. And a lot of that stuff’s bigger. And to the extent -- then comes my part to answer. Well, okay, can we see a way to creating value there? And if we can get some of the things that he's looking at done at prices that makes sense to us, then we're going to see the $1 billion and you may see more than $1 billion. If it stays exactly the way it's been for the last six months or nine months or 12 months, that's a risk. Because we're not going to hit that number to hit the number. We never have, we never will. And so it really is -- I don't know what to tell you, Laura, in terms of how to underwrite that. But I don't think the way to underwrite that is to say, "Well, okay, it's going to be $400 million or $200 million." It's either like 100 or $1 billion is kind of the way it's going to work. I don't know, Jeff, if you feel differently on that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't feel differently. And I think the finer point on what Don's saying is we're not going to change our criteria just to get deals done. There's going to be a lot of stuff to transact between now and the end of the year. And on the surface, you mi
componenttext: No, I don't feel differently. And I think the finer point on what Don's saying is we're not going to change our criteria just to get deals done. There's going to be a lot of stuff to transact between now and the end of the year. And on the surface, you might think it looks pretty good. But when we roll into the details on a lot of those assets, they’re just things that we didn't want to buy, because again, it doesn't give us what we want in the way of a platform for growing NOI over the medium to long term in a lot of these assets. So unless we see that in an asset and unless we can underwrite that and pay an appropriate price for it, we're not going to buy it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-05-2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, can I just add one thing to that? One of the things that we do, I think, pretty well is we go back. And we kind of lay out years later how we did on our underwriting assumptions on acquisitions. And this team has been together better part 10 years,
componenttext: Laura, can I just add one thing to that? One of the things that we do, I think, pretty well is we go back. And we kind of lay out years later how we did on our underwriting assumptions on acquisitions. And this team has been together better part 10 years, more than 10 years, and Jeff longer than that. And when we look at how we did, almost without fail, here's our big secret here. We missed the initial NOI projections in the first year or two. And we far exceed them in the later years. And it almost happens all the time. But when you look over a number, here’s how we did, we were really, really close. Missing a little early, getting a bit more later, and we're really, really close. So I don't think that as we're underwriting today, that we've got our head in the sand or that we're too Pollyanna-ish is in terms of what we're trying to underwrite. I think we're pretty good. I do think that some of the stuff that is being underwritten by others out there is just way too risky to believe that it's going to happen to put in underwriting numbers, they're like sellers underwriting numbers. So that's kind of the final point.
