headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Andy Blocher, and Chris Weilminster. These an
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Andy Blocher, and Chris Weilminster. These and other members of our management team are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. Our third quarter 2010 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained. 
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but are not limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of third quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina. Good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter FFO per share of $0.95 grew by 3.3% over prior year and significantly, that's the best quarter-over-quarter performance we've had since first quarter of '09. We expect that trend to continue into t
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina. Good afternoon, everyone. Our third quarter FFO per share of $0.95 grew by 3.3% over prior year and significantly, that's the best quarter-over-quarter performance we've had since first quarter of '09. We expect that trend to continue into the fourth quarter and therefore, feel comfortable guiding 2010 FFO per share to the now a range of $3.85 to $3.87. It also makes me optimistic that we'll be able to achieve the thus far elusive $4 a share threshold in 2011, as Andy will talk about later. Consumer spending remains sluggish and unemployment remains high, it's hard to expect much of a change over the next 12 months that way. But given those conditions, we were able to achieve $4 a share next year or even a bit higher. We'd be generating solid 4% growth plus a higher dividend over our near all-time earnings record this year, not growth over a significantly diluted year. In other words, no easy comps in Federal.
Separately, we just got some great news in the resolution of our lawsuit with Renato. That as you may remember, centered around our rights along with our partners' rights post property to buy the land under our Pentagon Row property. We won the suit earlier in the year and Renato petitioned for appeal for the Virginia Supreme Court shortly after that judgment. That petition was denied a couple of days ago. And we would therefore expect to close in the coming weeks or months on the land. It's a great deal and value enhancer to the entire Pentagon Row industry [ph]. 
Alright, let's dig into the quarter math a bit and start by talking about topline results and indications about expectations for the future topline growth. Rental income grew by 3.2% in the quarter including recoveries, which is basically a same-store number given the limited new activity in the last year or so. And that's a very good sign at the health of the portfolio. Cash basis leads rollover growth to 6% in the quarter, 17% on a straight-line basis. It's another good sign for higher future cash flows and that growth was pretty evenly spread between leases for new tenants and renewals of existing ones. Overall occupancy grew modestly year-over-year from 93.1% to 93.3%, solid, but we've got room to improve further there. At the rental income line, both for the quarter and looking into the future, portfolio continues to perform well and remains extremely solid and stable. 
Now during the quarter, higher expenses offset the topline growth resulting in flat same-center operating income and actually, slightly negative when you consider properties in various stages of redevelopment. Both of those larger properties and redevelopment, by the way, will be contributing beginning in the fourth quarter, if things [ph] come online and start paying rent. In addition, demolition cost and future redevelopment was also a factor in the quarter. Otherwise, the higher operating expenses during the quarter were mostly a matter of quarterly timing of various maintenance projects and don't affect our previous estimates of same-center operating growth for the full year of 1% to 1½%. In fact, it looks like it would be in the high end of that range or maybe even exceeded for the year.
If I went back and i looked at the forward-looking comments that I made on this call back in August concerning our view of the major markets we do business in, as well as the leasing and operating environment, and I've got to say it all still applies. Retailers want to get deals done in virtually all the markets we do business in, but with a tough cost conscious mentality that's here to stay in all of the best locations. Washington D.C. remains the strongest of our markets with California the weakest, though improving, particularly at Santana Row. All of the smaller potential acquisitions I talked about on the second quarter call are on track to close by the end of the year and will benefit 2011.
Let me spend a few minutes talking about some of the initiatives we're working on these days because between the developments, the redevelopment and the refinancing projects that we also have in various phases of execution, along with what feels to me a lot like more acquisition opportunities worth looking at. I'm optimistic that we're starting to see a clearer roadmap to additional value creation in the quarters and years ahead. Beginning with the most certain of value enhancers, so it's best to invest for us and start to [indiscernible] on our own. Our completely redeveloped $14 million building on Handed [ph] lane is done on time, on budget and is fully leased. Rent from all tenants, including the building's flagship Equinox Health club, begins during this fourth quarter and when combined with some key re-tenanting moves that were made elsewhere in the Bethesda really has helped one of our most successful mixed-use developments shift into an even higher gear. 
Out of Santana Row, we're well out of the ground on our 109-unit apartment building. Here also, we're on time and we're on budget thus far with rental prospect strong enough at the cost of the speed up planning on the next phase of residential development there, which would create an additional 150 to 200 apartments. Demand for our completed office over retail building in Santana has also picked up and the first rent-paying tenants there will begin contributing by the end of this year. In addition, we just executed a new lease with exclusive luxury electric car manufacturer, Tesla at Santana, which would be their first and only new prototypical showroom anywhere. Keep an eye on Santana over the next several years. There's a lots of momentum underway there.
Planning for a significant mixed-use development at Mid-Pike Plaza moves closer and closer to the zoning approvals and a viable phase  development plan that should have a lot of value to that great piece of land for the next 10-plus years, hopefully with first phase construction starting in 2012. And of course, Assembly Row, our project in Somerville, Massachusetts just outside of Boston. I have a pretty full update last quarter, which still applies including all my caveat. But it surely has promised, and since that last call, we've taken an handshake deal that we had with AvalonBay to buy the rights to build the first 400 apartments on this site. And as of yesterday, turns into a signed contract. Design now starts in earnest, and we hope to have a late 2011 construction start, if and in fact, pee stop [ph] construction of the site is imminent.
We'll know more about that in the next couple of months. And while we have no significant acquisitions to announce this quarter, we sure are working on a fair number of potential deals for some truly high quality stuff. Some street retail oriented product in the Northeast, some larger necessity based retail in both Florida and California, and a smattering of other strong quality properties in our remaining markets. All that has me encouraged that we'll be able to find a way to add products to our portfolio in the next couple of quarters that we can surely work over the next bunch of years.
Pricing expectations remain high by almost all standards, but at least it appears that the future earnings potential of these properties can justify. And that's a subtle change from what we've been seeing in the recent past. We're starting to see the first glimpses to a path of real estate value creation led by retailing and non-retail development and refinancing opportunities, along with some new raw materials in the form of high-quality real estate for sale that may be able to work into an even stronger position. That's all happening despite what remains a very challenging economic environment and a persistent futile longing for return to the good old days of 2006, 2007, it certainly isn't happening. 
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. And I'll turn it over to Andy, and look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to begin my prepared remarks with a more detailed review of our third quarter performance for a brief discussion of the balance sheet, and then an overview of our outlook and guidance for 2011. After th
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to begin my prepared remarks with a more detailed review of our third quarter performance for a brief discussion of the balance sheet, and then an overview of our outlook and guidance for 2011. After that, we'll turn the call over to your questions. 
To start, Federal Realty once again produced positive lease rollovers of 6% on a cash basis and 17% on a GAAP basis. We maintain physical occupancy levels in the portfolio of 93.3%. On the year-to-date basis, rollovers are 8% on the cash basis, 19% on the GAAP basis, very much in line with expectations we set with our initial 2010 guidance a year ago. Portfolio occupancy remains within the same tight range that we've seen throughout the past two years, really reflecting the strength of our end field portfolio even during tough economic times. Same-center NOI was flat excluding redevelopments and down 90 basis points including redevelopments compared to third quarter of '09. The redevelopment pool continues to be negatively impacted on a comparative basis due to the decline in lease term fee income largely because of the Home Depot lease term fee at Flourtown Shopping Center. These tougher lease term fee comps will continue to impact our quarterly same-center numbers through the first quarter of next year and have a meaningful impact on our projected same-center, including redevelopment number for full year 2011. In total, the $5 million expected decline in same-center lease term fees expected in '11 equates to roughly 150 basis points of same-center growth for the next few weeks.
As Don discussed, the topline growth of 3.2% was offset by higher operating expenses. The increase in operating expenses included an increase in demo cost and non-recovered pairs and maintenance. Demo cost, the largest impact of non-cam expenses in the quarter of about $500,000 are value-added expenses associated with getting spaces ready for occupancy by tenants such as Nordstrom Rack at Friendship Center, Neiman Marcus' Last Call Studio at Congressional, Dick's Sporting Goods at Governor Plaza, and LA Fitness in the associated redevelopment at Crossridge in Chicago. All strong lease feels signed over the past few quarters both from a rent and a merchandising perspective. While these four deals will minimally contribute a revenue in 2010, they are expected to generate almost $2 million in 2011 and will provide increased value beyond the rent contribution. Items such as demo costs, repairs and maintenance, and lease term fees can vary significantly from quarter-to-quarter, which is the primary reason we utilize full year resident [ph] quarterly guidance metrics in looking at our portfolio.
With respect to the balance sheet, we're really in a great position to play offense for the right properties. Very low leverage of 26% on a market cap basis and 42% on a book basis. Fixed-charge coverage more than 3x, debt to EBITDA of only 5x and secured debt making up only 13% of our total book assets. The quantity of the balance sheet is so important as many of the deals we're looking at today come with outsized in-place mortgage debt that we can absorb with little impact to our credit. In addition, we begun to process of choosing our leads for the recast of our credit facility that comes due in July next year. The man so far from high-quality financial institutions has been very strong, with banks generally focused on the best credits, making us confident in our ability to upsize a credit facility while setting a new standard for pricing. More to come on the credit facility recast as we move through the process early next year.
Before getting to the specifics of our guidance, let's focus on a couple of big picture items. The quality of our portfolio has allowed us to maintain very solid portfolio metrics throughout this economic downturn. 2008 property operating income was higher than 2007. 2009 was higher than 2008. 2010 is going to be higher than 2009, and we're expecting 2011 to be higher than 2010. I don't believe there's another peer out there that can point to that record of consistency during the same period. In addition, we've avoided material impairments, achieved positive lease rollover every year, maintained strong and steady occupancy, reserved the conservative balance sheet with no significant equity delusion and had paid an increased common dividend in cash. I couldn't be prouder of the performance of the portfolio and our employees over that period.
Moving on to guidance, we've tightened, not increased, our FFO per share guidance range for 2010 to $3.85 to $3.87. We're currently looking at full year 2010 property leasing, store property operating income growth at/or above the top end of our previous expectations of 1% to 1½% growth. Some of this growth was being offset FFO line due to increases in G&A, including over $0.01 associated with Don's new comp package, an acquisition cost of $700,000 or another $0.01 in 2010. In total, we're expecting our acquisitions to be slightly dilutive toward 2010 results, as the timing of these deals occurred late in the year and transaction cost or expense as the deals close.''
As for 2011, we're providing initial FFO per share guidance of $3.95 to $4.02, which will be record FFO per share performance despite economic pressures. A couple of key items to note here. First, with respect to occupancy, we're calling for a continuation of our steady occupancy with no material changes. Second, as we discussed on the first and second quarter calls, the acceleration of the Home Depot lease term fee provides a very though comp on this line item. We're calling for a $5 million decrease in lease term fees on a year-over-year basis with over $3 million coming from Home Depot alone. Despite this decrease, which equates to over 150 basis point impact to full year same-center growth, we're looking at positive same-center growth of 1% in 2011.
Don's new comp package results an additional $0.04 of G&A in 2011. And finally, consistent with prior years, we're not including any acquisition activity in this guidance. In addition, please recognize as we experienced in 2010, the expensing of acquisition costs will negatively impact FFO in the period the acquisition occurs. As a result, acquisitions could have a negative impact on full year FFO depending on the timing of any acquisitions we've made. 
That's all I've got. Operator, we'll now turn it over to questions.

componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering when I look at the portfolio and it sounds like you are starting to get some acquisition opportunity, does it make any sense to sell assets that are located in Detroit or San Antonio or some of the markets where you are not building kin
componenttext: I'm just wondering when I look at the portfolio and it sounds like you are starting to get some acquisition opportunity, does it make any sense to sell assets that are located in Detroit or San Antonio or some of the markets where you are not building kind of a crucial grouping of assets?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig. I mean, first of all, the answer to that whether they're in those markets, which for the reason you just said, are more likely to be disposed of or even in our core markets. The idea of balancing FFO growth with redeploying capital and certain
componenttext: Yes, Craig. I mean, first of all, the answer to that whether they're in those markets, which for the reason you just said, are more likely to be disposed of or even in our core markets. The idea of balancing FFO growth with redeploying capital and certainly your point of being able to do that better when there are acquisition opportunities is right on. And there's no question about that. We look very hard at each asset. We look at the value that we've created or not created over the last period of time and what it is that we expect to be able to do over the next five years or seven years, or to the extent we're sitting there and we're challenged. We're going to compare that with the ability to monetize it or to do something else with the asset. So yes, we're looking really hard at that. And I think you bring up the key point and that it's you have to be able to redeploy to capital. And so to the extent we've got opportunities in those prospects are better, clearly better than they've been, then you may see some of that.

componenttext: Yes, sure, Craig. i mean, again, it depends on the deal, right? The competition is many and varies on some deals, especially those that are fully marketed and takes the form now of private individuals that can mortgage that again and takes the form of our public peers. And of course, the pension fund advisers and operators backed by pension fund capital or competitors too and you generally see that all group, when an asset gets put on the market and fully marketed. As you know, a lot of our focus is trying to dig stuff up, dealing directly with owners and a lot of those cases we're the only ones talking to the owner or it's just a small group. And again, this a small group could have one or two from each of the major buyer groups that I mentioned just kind of depends on the deal and what it is and where it is really, a lot more as Dawn mentioned, a lot more properties that we like are coming to market and a lot more owners that own properties that we like are allowing to engage at a sale discussion today than they happen over the past four, five, six, seven quarters. So we're encouraged looking forward and I can tell you our group that handle that kind of stuff internally is busier than we've been in two or three years.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd add to that, Craig, is you got to remember, look, we're not a big acquisition shop, where we're trying to do lots and lots of deals all the time. So the population basis is smaller for us and it's only in certain markets, only the m
componenttext: And the only thing I'd add to that, Craig, is you got to remember, look, we're not a big acquisition shop, where we're trying to do lots and lots of deals all the time. So the population basis is smaller for us and it's only in certain markets, only the markets that we talked to you about. So I'm not sure that you can take those the comments we're making and really extrapolate them over the broader U.S. We're specifically saying that type of stuff that we like, we've looked at a lot of stuff that once we got in there, we don't like it. And there's more stuff that makes sense for Federal that we're seeing. Now whether we can cut deals or anything else, that's the million-dollar question, always. But there's more of it and that bodes well.

componenttextpreview: Don, you mentioned on your 2Q call that you could save headwinds in the second half of the year from small shop tenants that have been struggling for the past couple of years. Can you give us an update on what you're seeing today on the small shop side?
componenttext: Don, you mentioned on your 2Q call that you could save headwinds in the second half of the year from small shop tenants that have been struggling for the past couple of years. Can you give us an update on what you're seeing today on the small shop side?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're facing headwinds. What I was trying to say earlier in the year I think it's what's happening now and that is there are clearly in certain markets and particularly in certain property that have lots and lots of small shop space. Some of
componenttext: Yes, I think we're facing headwinds. What I was trying to say earlier in the year I think it's what's happening now and that is there are clearly in certain markets and particularly in certain property that have lots and lots of small shop space. Some of those tenants who are less well-capitalized are struggling. And they've been trying to figure out how they can keep going over the years whether it was some rent relief that they got, whether it was money for family or other places like that is and in some cases that's just not working out so well. And so we do see some of those going away, it's just not that much. And so one of the things that I looked at, in fact, I just took our board through yesterday was the amount of kind of a combination of bad debt and vacancies and rent relief. All of those things that deducts, if you will, from gross rent potential and where you seeing the kind of the second half a year plan out is actually very similar to the first half of the year and when you look 2010 over 2009, also very similar, not a lot better and not a lot worst. Now within that, there's always little nuances of changes between particular geographies or particular shopping centers within our portfolio. But overall, very consistent over the past couple of years , which is worse than it was two and three and four years ago, sadly.

componenttext: Yes, if we were looking at doing 10 or 12 or 15 kind of property acquisitions, you could say, well, a few of those are certainly going to close. Sooner rather than later, but you know, we don't buy all that much. And so as we do it, it's kind of an all or nothing. So I can tell you right now that we may be able to get some deals that we're looking at done in the first quarter of next year, the second quarter of next year, certainly. If they don't work out then we'll be looking further down the road, so it's a little bit more buying area at Federal, given the amount of acquisitions that we're likely to do. But I am not talking -- my comments, the more bullishness that you're hearing, I think appropriately so is more -- it's because of a nearer term possibility.

componenttext: No, look, it's lumpy. It's absolutely lumpy by its very nature and the first part of your question, I sure hope that you see more. I mean, the ability to incur a couple of hundred thousand dollars to knock down some basic governor shopping to be able to put in a new Dick's that changes the shopping center around will do all day long. And likewise its friendship, and the others said that Andy mentioned, I hope we have more of that's stuff that we have to do.  We will have more of that stuff to do, but it's not something that you could put in your model as an equal $500,000 each quarter, for example. It's lumpy.

componenttextpreview: I guess the question for you, Don, I'm curious to find about the trends you guys have been seeing specifically in small shop leasing and to differentiate, I guess between the local and regional tenants versus the national retailers? Because there really s
componenttext: I guess the question for you, Don, I'm curious to find about the trends you guys have been seeing specifically in small shop leasing and to differentiate, I guess between the local and regional tenants versus the national retailers? Because there really seem to be, I guess I'll say two worlds right now as it relates to levels of sales, profits and a desire to expand and I'm wondering if that applies to you guys in sort of your markets and the segment you operate in?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: To some extent, there's no question that when you take the Federal portfolio and you take the top 20%, the bottom 20%, the middle stuff, there's no question that the bottom 20% of Federal's shopping centers when I look at that at what the environment is t
componenttext: To some extent, there's no question that when you take the Federal portfolio and you take the top 20%, the bottom 20%, the middle stuff, there's no question that the bottom 20% of Federal's shopping centers when I look at that at what the environment is there, those centers in particular would have more issues with small shop tenants than elsewhere, the top 20% [indiscernible] is one of the strongest parts of the shopping center. So again, you kind of have to put geography trumps categorization of small shop regional and national. So within that context, when I look at -- I look at our bottom 20% and I think about some of the struggles we have in those centers of small shop and I do think, boy, if you're talking to another company that has more of that product side, it's a real issue. I get it, all day long. By the same token, if we had more of that top 20%, I think we'd be saying, "What? We don't even understand what the issue is that you're talking about." So first overall comment, you got to go to the quality of the real estate and see the differentiation by location. But overall, Chris, what do you think? Do you want to talk about that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, what we're seeing is a trend. It's really the quick-service restaurant category. They seem to be a very competitive environment right now on those categories where we're trying to find locations. Obviously, they're encumbered by parking restrictions
componenttext: Jeff, what we're seeing is a trend. It's really the quick-service restaurant category. They seem to be a very competitive environment right now on those categories where we're trying to find locations. Obviously, they're encumbered by parking restrictions and other things that really restrict the amount that a landlord could put within its portfolio, but that category, in general, seems to be very high know [ph] specific tenants but just that category as a whole. We are seeing in the marketplace, Don mentioned, that we're doing better in the D.C. market. We're seeing a lot more mom-and-pop oriented deals where they are coming in and back filling of the small shop vacancies. And then on a more national or regional basis, the anchor [indiscernible] certainly seems to be there for the right locations, but I think, Don, on a macro level, really summarized it very well. It really depends on the quality of real estate. They're looking for markets that have the attributes of Federal's portfolio against the population [indiscernible], places where they know it's basically [indiscernible] to open business and they can generate sales.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me do the Santana piece, in terms of what I was thinking there and let Dawn talk about the Avalon deals specially in terms of how it works in space, okay? On Santana, we looked at the timing of construction prices and we said, "There is no question th
componenttext: Let me do the Santana piece, in terms of what I was thinking there and let Dawn talk about the Avalon deals specially in terms of how it works in space, okay? On Santana, we looked at the timing of construction prices and we said, "There is no question that any time anybody is living or staying even overnight at Santana in the form of either the hotel, the rental product that we have or the condos." That it carries such a premium because of what happened on the ground floor and even though, look, it's an awful top tough time to be adding new product, if you sit and think about it in the worst part of 2009 when we started, we simply know we can get the right construction costs to get this done, and we know that we're going to get that building filled up. And so we started and so as we got into this, we got more and more comfortable that yes, in fact, it was what's going to happen. There was real demand and look, we haven't leased one of those 109 units yet. It's under construction. So it's still just speculative. But it looks good enough to me, and we know we'll make some money someday for sure on the condo. I'm converting to condos but it looks we're going to make some good money just on the rentals, so much so that we kind of took the -- we've taken a hard look at the next piece of land, which we weren't going to do until we saw how this first project worked out behind, it's called Building A, one of the other buildings there. And so we'd like to get on it and jump on it now, and get started on it, which we are. So that positive outlook has everything to do with a specific location in field of Santana and I was trying to -- just kind of trying to allude to in my comments, Bethesda Row and Santana Row are two great examples of places where we really are seeing amazing traction these days. And part of it's maturity of the property. Part of it is maturity of the merchandising mix and some tweaking that we're doing there. But there's some momentum at that type of product that's one of the things we like about the first couple of buildings certainly on Newbury, certainly what we like about Third Street Promenade. So very positive stuff that way. It's also impacting how we feel about Assemble, in terms of what Assembly could be down the road. And so maybe let me leave it at that and just ask your question about the ABB deal to Dawn.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, let me give you a little perspective on what we've got planned with Avalon if you understand in the context of the project. What we've talked to Avalon about is really they'll be coming in with us on the first phase of the development, which wo
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, let me give you a little perspective on what we've got planned with Avalon if you understand in the context of the project. What we've talked to Avalon about is really they'll be coming in with us on the first phase of the development, which would be three buildings to really get the project started with 400 residential units and about 225,000 square feet of retail to supplement the assembly Square Mall, which has 300,000-plus square feet of retail just across away from it. So it's the first starting point and what we have worked through with Avalon right now are really how we're going to build this project together. And much as you've seen before with us, Avalon is going to build the project, we buyback the retail. So we'll control the retail long term, Avalon will control the residential long term. I don't want to get into financial specifics of anything at this point. But that's the groundwork for it. And where we are at this point is everybody is working hard on the Avalon side on their due diligence to confirm where they are. And I think based on everything we've seen and the work they've done in advance, everyone is feeling very positive that from their perspective on the residential that we've got a good project going forward and we're seeing some really great interest from a lot of the retailers we're talking about, particularly entertainment venues as well as retail, as well as the restaurants out there. So that's how it's going to play out over the next several months. With hopefully the public funding coming together, so sometime I think as Don said towards the end of '11, we'd be able to have all the pieces really hitting our stride and get that first phase of development up and running to be the catalyst for the rest of the development out there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually on Assembly Square and maybe this is for you, Don and for Andy, I'm just trying to think, I guess maybe about NAV, if you will. Maybe give us some pieces because I think your gross investment there is about $190 million, but I'm assuming tha
componenttext: It's actually on Assembly Square and maybe this is for you, Don and for Andy, I'm just trying to think, I guess maybe about NAV, if you will. Maybe give us some pieces because I think your gross investment there is about $190 million, but I'm assuming that exceeds sort of what I would assumed is justified by the NOI that throws off today. Are you able to share with us what the NOI is at Assembly Square, so maybe we can guesstimate how much investment you've made sort of in the future over the project, if you will that doesn't really cash flow today?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will give you a couple of points of where we were. When we bought the property we spent $100 million on the existing mall and the completion of that existing mall and that threw off about around $7 million. And really from the beginning of this thi
componenttext: Yes, I will give you a couple of points of where we were. When we bought the property we spent $100 million on the existing mall and the completion of that existing mall and that threw off about around $7 million. And really from the beginning of this thing, I said well, okay we're sitting there with a yielding landslide. It started at seven basically which I viewed wonderfully, in terms of starting with that and having this other big piece of land behind it. Now we have a bunch more of that land to buy if we wanted to do something and we have done that over the years. But so we started 100 with the seven. We did knock down on the existing development site about $1.5 million worth of some pretty sloppy retail, but no offense to anybody [indiscernible] but pretty sloppy retail, a couple of years back. And so we've got remaining about $5.5 million or so of income. At the same time we bought a lot of additional pieces of land and so you're absolutely right, $190 million is certainly is not supported by $5.5 million of NOI, in terms of a value creation, value creative proposition, works for accounting not value creation. And so the idea of what we do going forward, how we do it in pieces, we're doing very much on a phase by phase justifiable basis, and this would be the first phase of development. In my view, it's second phase of Assembly Row.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Federal Realty Investment Trust Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I would like to introduce the conference leader, Ms. Gina Birdsall. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's third quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Andy Blocher, and Chris Weilminster. These an
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon. I'd like to thank everyone for joining us today for Federal Realty's third quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Don Wood, Dawn Becker, Jeff Berkes, Andy Blocher, and Chris Weilminster. These and other members of our management team are available to take your questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. Our third quarter 2010 supplemental disclosure package provides a significant amount of valuable information with respect to the Trust's operating and financial performance. This document is currently available on our website.
Certain matters discussed on this call may be deemed to be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements include any annualized or projected information, as well as statements referring to expected or anticipated events or results. Although Federal Realty believes the expectations reflected in such forward-looking statements are based on reasonable assumptions, Federal Realty's future operations and its actual performance may differ materially from the information contained in our forward-looking statements, and we can give no assurance that these expectations will be attained. 
Risks inherent in these assumptions include, but are not limited to, future economic conditions including interest rates, real estate conditions and the risks and costs of construction. The earnings release and supplemental reporting package that we issued yesterday, our annual report filed on Form 10-K and our other financial disclosure documents provide a more in-depth discussion of risk factors that may affect our financial condition and results of operations. 
I'll now turn the call over to Don Wood to begin our discussion of third quarter results. Don?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gina. Good afternoon, everyone. Third quarter FFO per share of $0.95 grew by 3.3% over the prior year and significantly, that's the best quarter-over-quarter performance we've had since first quarter of '09. We would expect that trend to continue
componenttext:
Thanks, Gina. Good afternoon, everyone. Third quarter FFO per share of $0.95 grew by 3.3% over the prior year and significantly, that's the best quarter-over-quarter performance we've had since first quarter of '09. We would expect that trend to continue into the fourth quarter and therefore, feel comfortable guiding 2010 FFO per share to the narrow range of $3.85 to $3.87. It also makes me optimistic that we'll be able to achieve the thus far elusive $4 a share threshold in 2011, as Andy will talk about later. Consumer spending remains sluggish and unemployment remains high, it's hard to expect much of a change over the next 12 months that way. But given those conditions, if we were able to achieve $4 a share next year or even a bit higher, we'd be generating solid 4% growth plus the higher dividend over a near all-time earnings record this year, not growth over a significantly diluted year. In other words, no easy comps at Federal.
Separately, we just got some great news in the resolution of our lawsuit with Renato that as you may remember, centered around our rights, along with our partners' rights, Post Property, to buy the land under our Pentagon Row property. We won the suit earlier in the year and Renato petitioned for appeal to the Virginia Supreme Court shortly after that judgment. That petition was denied a couple of days ago, and we would therefore expect to close in the coming weeks or months on the land. It's a great deal and value enhancer to the entire Pentagon Row income stream. 
Alright, let's dig into the quarter a bit and start by talking about top line results and indications about expectations for the future top line growth. Rental income grew by 3.2% in the quarter including recoveries, which is basically a same-store number given the limited new activity in the last year or so. And that's a very good sign as to the health of the portfolio. Cash basis leads rollover growth 6% in the quarter, 17% on a straight-line basis. It's another good sign for higher future cash flows and that growth was pretty evenly spread between leases for new tenants and renewals of existing ones. Overall occupancy grew modestly year-over-year from 93.1% to 93.3%, solid, but we've got room to improve further there. At the rental income line, both for the quarter and looking into the future, portfolio continues to perform well and remains extremely solid and stable. 
Now during the quarter, higher expenses offset the top line growth resulting in flat same-center operating income and actually, it was slightly negative when you consider properties in various stages of redevelopment. Both of those larger properties and redevelopment, by the way, will be contributing beginning in the fourth quarter, as tenants come online and start paying rent. In addition, demolition cost and future redevelopment was also a factor in the quarter. Otherwise, the higher operating expenses during the quarter were mostly a matter of quarterly timing of various maintenance projects and don't affect our previous estimates of same-center operating income growth for the full year of 1% to 1½%. In fact, it looks like we'll be at the high end of that range or maybe even exceed it for the year.
I went back and I looked at the forward-looking comments that I made on this call back in August concerning our view of the major markets we do business in, as well as the leasing and operating environment, and I've got to say it all still applies. Retailers want to get deals done in virtually all the markets we do business in, but with a tough cost conscious mentality that's here to stay in all but the best locations. Washington D.C. remains the strongest of our markets with California the weakest, though improving, particularly at Santana Row. All of the smaller potential acquisitions I talked about on the second quarter call are on track to close by the end of the year and will benefit 2011.
Let me spend a few minutes talking about some of the initiatives we're working on these days because between the developments, the redevelopments and the re-tenanting projects that we also have in various phases of execution, along with what feels to me a lot like more acquisition opportunities worth looking at, I'm optimistic that we're starting to see a clearer roadmap to additional value creation in the quarters and years ahead. Beginning with the most certain of value enhancers, it's always been for us to start in Bethesda Row. Our completely redeveloped $14 million building on Hampden Lane is done on time, on budget and is fully leased. Rent from all tenants, including the building's flagship Equinox Health Club, begins during this fourth quarter and when combined with some key re-tenanting moves that were made elsewhere in Bethesda really has helped one of our most successful mixed-use developments shift into an even higher gear. 
Out at Santana Row, we're well out of the ground on our 109-unit apartment building. Here also, we're on time and we're on budget thus far with rental prospect strong enough as to cause us to speed up planning on the next phase of residential development there, which would create an additional 150 to 200 apartments. Demand for our completed office over retail building in Santana has also picked up and the first rent-paying tenants there will begin contributing by the end of this year. In addition, we just executed a new lease with exclusive luxury electric car manufacturer, Tesla at Santana, which would be their first and only new prototypical showroom anywhere. Keep an eye on Santana over the next several years. There's lots of momentum underway there.
Planning for a significant mixed-use development at Mid-Pike Plaza moves closer and closer to the zoning approvals and a viable phase development plan that should add a lot of value to that great piece of land for the next 10-plus years, hopefully with first phase construction starting in 2012. And of course, Assembly Row, our project in Somerville, Massachusetts just outside of Boston. I gave a pretty full update last quarter, which still applies, including all my caveats. But it surely has promise and since that last call, we've taken the handshake deal that we had with AvalonBay to buy the rights to build the first 400 apartments on the site and as of yesterday, turned it into a signed contract. Design now starts in earnest, and we hope to have a late 2011 construction start, if and in fact, T-Stop construction at the site is imminent. We'll know more about that in the next couple of months.
And while we have no significant acquisitions to announce this quarter, we sure are working on a fair number of potential deals for some truly high quality stuff. Some street retail oriented product in the Northeast, some larger necessity based retail in both Florida and California, and a smattering of other strong quality properties in our remaining markets. All that has me encouraged that we'll be able to find a way to add product to our portfolio in the next couple of quarters that we can surely work over the next bunch of years.
Pricing expectations remain high by almost all standards, but at least it appears that the future earnings potential of these properties can justify then. And that's a subtle change from what we've been seeing in the recent past. We're starting to see the first glimpses to a path of real estate value creation led by retail and non-retail development and re-tenanting opportunities, along with some new raw material in the form of high-quality real estate for sale that may be able to work into an even stronger position. That's all happening despite what remains a very challenging economic environment and a persistent futile longing for a return to the good old days of 2006, 2007. It certainly isn't happening. 
That's all I've got for my prepared remarks this morning. And I'll turn it over to Andy, and look forward to your questions after that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to begin my prepared remarks with a more detailed review of our third quarter performance for a brief discussion of the balance sheet, and then an overview of our outlook and guidance for 2011. After th
componenttext:
Thanks, Don, and good afternoon, everyone. I'm going to begin my prepared remarks with a more detailed review of our third quarter performance for a brief discussion of the balance sheet, and then an overview of our outlook and guidance for 2011. After that, we'll turn the call over to your questions. 
To start, Federal Realty once again produced positive lease rollovers of 6% on a cash basis and 17% on a GAAP basis. We maintain physical occupancy levels in the portfolio of 93.3%. On the year-to-date basis, rollovers are 8% on a cash basis, 19% on a GAAP basis, very much in line with the expectations we set with our initial 2010 guidance a year ago. Portfolio occupancy remains within the same tight range that we've seen throughout the past two years, really reflecting the strength of our end field portfolio, even during tough economic times. Same-center NOI was flat excluding redevelopments and down 90 basis points including redevelopments compared to third quarter of '09. The redevelopment pool continues to be negatively impacted on a comparative basis due to the decline in lease term fee income largely because of the Home Depot lease term fee at Flourtown Shopping Center. These tougher lease term fee comps will continue to impact our quarterly same-center numbers through the first quarter of next year and have a meaningful impact upon our projected same-center, including redevelopment number for full year 2011. In total, the $5 million expected decline in same-center lease term fees expected in '11 equates to roughly 150 basis points of same-center growth for the next year.
As Don discussed, the top line growth of 3.2% was offset by higher operating expenses. The increase in operating expenses included an increase in demo costs and non-recovered pairs and maintenance. Demo cost, the largest impact of non-cam expenses in the quarter of about $500,000 are value-added expenses associated with getting spaces ready for occupancy by tenants such as Nordstrom Rack at Friendship Center, Neiman Marcus' Last Call Studio at Congressional, Dick's Sporting Goods at Governor Plaza, and LA Fitness in the associated redevelopment at Crossridge in Chicago, all strong lease deals signed over the past few quarters both from a rent and a merchandising perspective. While these four deals will minimally contribute a revenue in 2010, they are expected to generate almost $2 million in 2011 and will provide increased value beyond a rent contribution. Items such as demo costs, repairs and maintenance, and lease term fees can vary significantly from quarter-to-quarter, which is the primary reason we utilize full year resident [ph] quarterly guidance metrics in looking at our portfolio.
With respect to the balance sheet, we're really in a great position to play offense for the right properties. Very low leverage of 26% on a market cap basis and 42% on a book basis. Fixed-charge coverage more than 3x, debt to EBITDA of only 5x and secured debt making up only 13% of our total book assets. The quality of the balance sheet is so important, as many of the deals we're looking at today come with outsized in-place mortgage debt that we can absorb with little impact to our credit. In addition, we've begun the process of choosing our leads for the recast of our credit facility that comes due in July of next year. Demand so far from high-quality financial institutions has been very strong, with banks generally focused on the best credits, making us confident in our ability to upsize a credit facility while setting a new standard for pricing. More to come on the credit facility recast as we move through the process early next year.
Before getting to the specifics of our guidance, let's focus on a couple of big picture items. The quality of our portfolio has allowed us to maintain very solid portfolio metrics throughout this economic downturn. 2008 property operating income was higher than 2007. 2009 was higher than 2008. 2010's going to be higher than 2009, and we're expecting 2011 to be higher than 2010. I don't believe there's another peer out there that can point to that record of consistency during the same period. In addition, we've avoided material impairments, achieved positive lease rollover every year, maintained strong and steady occupancy, reserved a conservative balance sheet with no significant equity delusion and had paid an increased common dividend in cash. I couldn't be prouder of the performance of the portfolio and our employees over that period.
Moving on to guidance, we've tightened, not increased, our FFO per share guidance range for 2010 to $3.85 to $3.87. We're currently looking at full year 2010 property, a same-store property operating income growth at/or above the top end of our previous expectations of 1% to 1½% growth. Some of this growth is being offset at the FFO line due to increases in G&A, including over $0.01 associated with Don's new comp package, and acquisition costs of $700,000 or another $0.01 in 2010. In total, we're expecting our acquisitions to be slightly dilutive to our 2010 results, as the timing of these deals occurred late in the year and transaction costs or expense as the deals close.
As for 2011, we're providing initial FFO per share guidance of $3.95 to $4.02, which will be record FFO per share performance despite the economic pressures. A couple of key items to note here. First, with respect to occupancy, we're calling for a continuation of our steady occupancy with no material changes. Second, as we discussed on the first and second quarter calls, the acceleration of the Home Depot lease term fee provides a very though comp on this line item. We're calling for a $5 million decrease in lease term fees on a year-over-year basis with over $3 million coming from Home Depot alone. Despite this decrease, which equates to over 150 basis point impact to full year same-center growth, we're looking at positive same-center growth of 1% in 2011.
Don's new comp package results in an additional $0.04 of G&A in 2011. And finally, consistent with prior years, we're not including any acquisition activity in this guidance. In addition, please recognize as we experienced in 2010, the expensing of acquisition costs will negatively impact FFO in the period the acquisition occurs. As a result, acquisitions could have a negative impact on full year FFO, depending on the timing of any acquisitions we've made. 
That's all I've got. Operator, we'll now turn it over to questions.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from the line of Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering when I look at the portfolio and it sounds like you are starting to get some acquisition opportunity, does it make any sense to sell assets that are located in Detroit or San Antonio or some of the markets where you are not building kin
componenttext: I'm just wondering when I look at the portfolio and it sounds like you are starting to get some acquisition opportunity, does it make any sense to sell assets that are located in Detroit or San Antonio or some of the markets where you are not building kind of a crucial grouping of assets?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig. I mean, first of all, the answer to that whether they're in those markets, which for the reason you just said, are more likely to be disposed of or even in our core markets. The idea of balancing FFO growth with redeploying capital and certain
componenttext: Yes, Craig. I mean, first of all, the answer to that whether they're in those markets, which for the reason you just said, are more likely to be disposed of or even in our core markets. The idea of balancing FFO growth with redeploying capital and certainly your point of being able to do that better when there are acquisition opportunities is right on. And there's no question about that. We look very hard at each asset. We look at the value that we've created or not created over the last period of time and what it is that we expect to be able to do over the next five years or seven years. And to the extent we're sitting there and we're challenged, we're going to compare that with the ability to monetize it or to do something else with the asset. So yes, we're looking really hard at that. And I think you bring up the key point and that is, you have to be able to redeploy to capital. And so to the extent we've got opportunities and those prospects are better, clearly better than they've been, then you may see some of that.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the prospects, are you running into any other public companies or are these your typical relationship deals?
componenttext: And on the prospects, are you running into any other public companies or are these your typical relationship deals?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little of both. But Jeff, are you on the call from California? Can you talk to that?
componenttext: A little of both. But Jeff, are you on the call from California? Can you talk to that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Craig. I mean, again, it depends on the deal, right? The competition is many and varies on some deals, especially those that are fully marketed and takes the form now of private individuals that can mortgage that again and takes the form of our
componenttext: Yes, sure, Craig. I mean, again, it depends on the deal, right? The competition is many and varies on some deals, especially those that are fully marketed and takes the form now of private individuals that can mortgage that again and takes the form of our public peers. And of course, the pension fund advisers and operators backed by pension fund capital are competitors too and you generally see that whole group when an asset gets put on the market and fully marketed. As you know, a lot of our focus is trying to dig stuff up, dealing directly with owners and a lot of those cases we're the only ones talking to the owner or it's just a small group. And again, this a small group. We could have one or two from each of the major buyer groups that I mentioned; just kind of depends on the deal and what it is and where it is. You think really, it's a lot more. As Dawn mentioned, a lot more properties that we like are coming to market and a lot more owners that own properties that we like are willing to engage in a sale discussion today than they have been over the past four, five, six, seven quarters. So we're encouraged looking forward and I can tell you our group that handles that kind of stuff internally is busier than we've been in two or three years.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: You seem to have a different attitude. So has it has been as recent as maybe the last three months, or I've just not paying close attention?
componenttext: You seem to have a different attitude. So has it has been as recent as maybe the last three months, or I've just not paying close attention?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think if you kind of dial back to what I said on last quarter's conference call, I think I indicated that the activity had picked up. So it's something that we've been seeing build over the last handful of quarters. But it's been clearly evident the
componenttext: No, I think if you kind of dial back to what I said on last quarter's conference call, I think I indicated that the activity had picked up. So it's something that we've been seeing build over the last handful of quarters. But it's been clearly evident the last six months or so.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the only thing I'd add to that, Craig, is you got to remember, look, we're not a big acquisition shop where we're trying to do lots and lots of deals all the time. So the population basis is smaller for us and it's only in certain markets, the markets
componenttext: And the only thing I'd add to that, Craig, is you got to remember, look, we're not a big acquisition shop where we're trying to do lots and lots of deals all the time. So the population basis is smaller for us and it's only in certain markets, the markets that we talked to you about. So I'm not sure that you can take those, the comments we're making, and really extrapolate them over the broader U.S. We're specifically saying that type of stuff that we like, we've looked at a lot of stuff that once we got in there, we don't like it. And there's more stuff that makes sense for Federal that we're seeing. Now whether we can cut deals or anything else, that's the million-dollar question, always. But there's more of it and that bodes well.

componenttext: I did not. That's not true. Yes, I said total revenue growth was 3.2% and that's pretty darn close to same-store because we don't have a lot of new stuff in there in those two periods. And whether that's two point there -- I don't know exactly what it would be, but yes, it's 3%, roughly 3%.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: And if you sort of split out -- so if your same-store revenue growth was up 3%, so your same-store expenses were up, what were the big drivers of expense growth?

componenttext: So part of that revenue growth is going to be is reimbursements that we're getting. So we had higher expenses as you imagine per cam items, which are contributing to some of that revenue growth. And then in addition to that, we had the biggest impact was really non-cam related and the biggest impact for the non-cam bucket was demo as I referred to, which is over $500,000. So that's really what's driving that and a lot of timing of the maintenance projects that particularly happened in the third quarter versus different parts of the year. That's all.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that we laid out both in the release and on the call. We're really looking at very flat occupancy. We certainly didn't lose the level of occupancy during the downturn, so we're at pretty stable occupancy right now. Rollover growth on a cash basis, we're probably looking at -- what we looked at in 2010 kind of high single digits on the positive.

componenttext: We have a general reserve basically for vacancies that is not specifically based, but it's based on our historical experience in terms of what's happening. So we cover it, yes, with an overall vacancy allowance, but it's not specific to any particular retailer.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Laura Clark with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Laura Clark with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Don, you mentioned on your 2Q call that you could save headwinds in the second half of the year from small shop tenants that have been struggling for the past couple of years. Can you give us an update on what you're seeing today on the small shop side?
componenttext: Don, you mentioned on your 2Q call that you could save headwinds in the second half of the year from small shop tenants that have been struggling for the past couple of years. Can you give us an update on what you're seeing today on the small shop side?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're facing headwinds. What I was trying to say earlier in the year I think is what's happening now and that is there are clearly in certain markets and particularly in certain property that have lots and lots of small shop space. Some of th
componenttext: Yes, I think we're facing headwinds. What I was trying to say earlier in the year I think is what's happening now and that is there are clearly in certain markets and particularly in certain property that have lots and lots of small shop space. Some of those tenants who are less well capitalized are struggling. And they've been trying to figure out how they can keep going over the years whether it was some rent relief that they got, whether it was money from family or other places like that is and in some cases that's just not working out so well. And so we do see some of those going away, it's just not that much. And so one of the things that I looked at, in fact, I just took our board through yesterday, was the amount of kind of a combination of bad debt and vacancies and rent relief. All of those things that deduct, if you will, from gross rent potential and where you see is kind of the second half a year plan out is actually very similar to the first half of the year and when you look 2010 over 2009, also very similar, not a lot better and not a lot worse. Now within that, there's always little nuances of changes between particular geographies or particular shopping centers within our portfolio. But overall, very consistent over the past couple of years, which is worse than it was two and three and four years ago, sadly.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So essentially you're not expecting kind of further fallout, just kind of more on the same?
componenttext: So essentially you're not expecting kind of further fallout, just kind of more on the same?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think more the same is exactly right.
componenttext: I think more the same is exactly right.

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I think that could make a lot of sense. It does come down though to; always, use of proceeds.  And Andy and I are talking about that a bunch. It's tied in with some of the conversations Jeff and I are having with respect to acquisitions, but no, there's no question. These are unprecedented times, and to the extent we could capitalize the company with some longer-term money at rates like this, we'd love to do it all day long.

componenttextpreview: Right. And Laura, I mean, right now, we've got about $30 million growing on the line. We got to find, as Don said, there's great use of proceeds and now is a great time to try to finance that. But key to that is our lack of desire to sacrifice quality in
componenttext: Right. And Laura, I mean, right now, we've got about $30 million growing on the line. We got to find, as Don said, there's great use of proceeds and now is a great time to try to finance that. But key to that is our lack of desire to sacrifice quality in what it is that we're pursuing.

componenttext: Where would you be comfortable taking your leverage to?

componenttext: There's a few metrics you got to talk about when you think about that. It's not only debt-to-book value, debt-to-market value, debt-to-EBITDA, et cetera. I would tell you that the ability for this company to put on another few hundred million dollars worth of debt would be very, very easily manageable. It could be more than that, but when you say it comes out, certainly a few hundred million dollars.

componenttext: On the TI line, on the TI spend line, I noticed that kind of jumped in the quarter, is there anything unique going on there as far as TIs for new leases?
