componenttext: There is not. We kind of talk about this each time. With our company, we do 300 deals a year and whatever that means. 75 deals a quarter, so it very much depends on the specific deals. I think if you take a look at it over this year even over last year, there's a lot of variability within the quarter because of specific deals that happened in a particular quarter, but there's no trend to draw.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then turning for a second back to acquisitions, as you guys look at it next year, what's going on? I mean, do you have -- I mean, I know you're getting a little more excited, but is there stuff near term in the pipeline that you think could close in t
componenttext: And then turning for a second back to acquisitions, as you guys look at it next year, what's going on? I mean, do you have -- I mean, I know you're getting a little more excited, but is there stuff near term in the pipeline that you think could close in the first couple of quarters? Is it bad, good or are we still kind of looking down the road a bit at possibilities?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, if we were looking at doing 10 or 12 or 15 kind of property acquisitions, you could say, well, a few of those are certainly going to close sooner rather than later, but you know, we don't buy all that much. And so as we do it, it's kind of an all or
componenttext: Yes, if we were looking at doing 10 or 12 or 15 kind of property acquisitions, you could say, well, a few of those are certainly going to close sooner rather than later, but you know, we don't buy all that much. And so as we do it, it's kind of an all or nothing. So I can tell you right now that we may be able to get some deals that we're looking at done in the first quarter of next year, the second quarter of next year, certainly. If they don't work out then we'll be looking further down the road, so it's a little bit more binary at Federal, given the amount of acquisitions that we're likely to do. But I am not talking -- my comments, the more bullishness that you're hearing, I think appropriately so is more -- is because of a nearer term possibility.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it a mix -- I mean what kind of mix of product is coming out there? I realize you guys are looking for a certain set of things, but what are you seeing come to the market, is it still a lot of A-type core stuff or is there a whole mix of Bs and Cs and
componenttext: Is it a mix -- I mean what kind of mix of product is coming out there? I realize you guys are looking for a certain set of things, but what are you seeing come to the market, is it still a lot of A-type core stuff or is there a whole mix of Bs and Cs and just -- is the whole environment I guess changing from where we were say, six months ago or do you not really see it that way?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to the first comment that I was making. I don't know that we're the best guys to give you a comment on how the whole United States or broader than that is going this way. In the markets that we're seeing that we're doing business in, in
componenttext: I want to go back to the first comment that I was making. I don't know that we're the best guys to give you a comment on how the whole United States or broader than that is going this way. In the markets that we're seeing that we're doing business in, in the A-product type that we are trying to find, we're looking as I said at some street retail stuff in the northeast. That's A quality stuff without question. We're looking at some larger necessity based stuff in both Florida and California, again, that's A-quality stuff that we hadn't been seen before. All this stuff is very expensive. But in those markets, in the -- both the necessity base and street retail stuff in those markets, we're simply seeing more.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the very last thing is on the demo charges that you guys had in the same quarter, do we see more of that? I mean, how does that work? Did you kind of do what you were going to do and now we take a break and it's kind of lumpy or is it sort of ste
componenttext: And then the very last thing is on the demo charges that you guys had in the same quarter, do we see more of that? I mean, how does that work? Did you kind of do what you were going to do and now we take a break and it's kind of lumpy or is it sort of steady?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, look, it's lumpy. It's absolutely lumpy by its very nature and the first part of your question, I sure hope that you see more. I mean, the ability to incur a couple of hundred thousand dollars to knock down some space at Governor Shopping Center to be
componenttext: No, look, it's lumpy. It's absolutely lumpy by its very nature and the first part of your question, I sure hope that you see more. I mean, the ability to incur a couple of hundred thousand dollars to knock down some space at Governor Shopping Center to be able to put in a new Dick's that changes the shopping center around, we'll do all day long. And likewise it's Friendship, and the others said that Andy mentioned, I hope we have more of that stuff to do. We will have more of that stuff to do, but it's not something you can put in your model as an equal $500,000 each quarter, for example. It's lumpy.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the question for you, Don, I'm curious to find about the trends you guys have been seeing specifically in small shop leasing and to differentiate, I guess between the local and regional tenants versus the national retailers, because there really s
componenttext: I guess the question for you, Don, I'm curious to find about the trends you guys have been seeing specifically in small shop leasing and to differentiate, I guess between the local and regional tenants versus the national retailers, because there really seem to be, I guess I'll say two worlds right now as it relates to unit level sales, profits and a desire to expand and I'm wondering if that applies to you guys in sort of your markets and the segment you operate in?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: To some extent. There's no question that when you take the Federal portfolio and you take the top 20%, the bottom 20% and the middle stuff, there's no question that the bottom 20% of Federal's shopping centers, when I look at that at what the environment
componenttext: To some extent. There's no question that when you take the Federal portfolio and you take the top 20%, the bottom 20% and the middle stuff, there's no question that the bottom 20% of Federal's shopping centers, when I look at that at what the environment is there, those centers in particular would have more issues with small shop tenants than elsewhere, the top 20%, the Bethesda Row [indiscernible] is one of the strongest parts of the shopping center. So again, you kind of have to put -- geography trumps categorization of small shop regional and national. So within that context, when I look at -- I look at our bottom 20% and I think about some of the struggles we have in those centers on small shop and I do think, boy, if you're talking to another company that has more of that product type, it's a real issue. I get it, all day long. By the same token, if we had more of that top 20%, I think we'd be saying, "What? We don't even understand what the issue is that you're talking about." So first overall comment, you got to go to the quality of the real estate and see the differentiation by location. But overall, Chris, what do you think? Do you want to talk about that?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, what we're seeing as a trend is really the quick-service restaurant category. This seems to be a very competitive environment right now on those categories, really trying to find locations. Obviously, they're encumbered by parking restrictions and o
componenttext: Jeff, what we're seeing as a trend is really the quick-service restaurant category. This seems to be a very competitive environment right now on those categories, really trying to find locations. Obviously, they're encumbered by parking restrictions and other things that really restrict the amount that a landlord could put within its portfolio, but that category, in general, seems to be very high. No specific tenant, but just that category as a whole. We are seeing in the marketplace, Don mentioned that we're doing better in the D.C. market. We're seeing a lot more mom-and-pop oriented deals, where they are coming in and back filling of the small shop vacancies. And then on a more national regional basis, the anchor tenant interest certainly seems to be there for the right locations, but I think Don, on a macro level, really summarized it very well. It really depends on the quality of real estate. They're looking for markets that have the attributes of Federal's portfolio density of population, various to entry, places where they know it's basically a no-brainer for them to open business and they can generate sales.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it more important in those mom-and-pop instances businesses that the space is already built out?
componenttext: Is it more important in those mom-and-pop instances businesses that the space is already built out?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it helps. It helps them retain capital for operations. It's a new build out. But if it's the right piece of real estate, they're going to take the real estate and they'll figure out a way to come up with the capital to build out, if that's what it
componenttext: I guess it helps. It helps them retain capital for operations. It's a new build out. But if it's the right piece of real estate, they're going to take the real estate and they'll figure out a way to come up with the capital to build out, if that's what it takes.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just to switch gears, Don, I'm just curious. Has there any movement -- I know it's been early -- on the assets, I guess it's Urban Meritage?
componenttext: And just to switch gears, Don, I'm just curious. Has there any movement -- I know it's been early -- on the assets, I guess it's Urban Meritage?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Boston on Newbury?
componenttext: In Boston on Newbury?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's only the first six months. It's funny, Jeff, you asked that, because I was really going back and forth as to whether to put Newbury into our prepared remarks or not. I decided not to, because it is early. Having said that, we're very pleased wit
componenttext: Yes, it's only the first six months. It's funny, Jeff, you asked that, because I was really going back and forth as to whether to put Newbury into our prepared remarks or not. I decided not to, because it is early. Having said that, we're very pleased with the activity that we're seeing, particularly as it relates to what we underwrote. So I didn't want to say that, I guess because it's too early, but I just said it and that's how I feel.

componenttextpreview: But I believe like -- I guess where I was thinking about is Torres, I think a partner, you recall, having some issues and one might be able to piece together there could be some catalyst there for some assets being sold. Has there been any movement there
componenttext: But I believe like -- I guess where I was thinking about is Torres, I think a partner, you recall, having some issues and one might be able to piece together there could be some catalyst there for some assets being sold. Has there been any movement there or is it still a little early?

componenttext: Well, first of all, that's a very good idea. And we agree with you, but it's too early to talk about it.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could, a few questions actually on Assembly Square, are you able to talk a little bit about the terms of the deal with Avalon and how that will work? And then I think you mentioned something about the additional residential at Santana, I'm curiou
componenttext: And if I could, a few questions actually on Assembly Square, are you able to talk a little bit about the terms of the deal with Avalon and how that will work? And then I think you mentioned something about the additional residential at Santana, I'm curious what your thoughts were.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me do the Santana piece, in terms of what I was thinking there and let Dawn talk about the Avalon deals specifically in terms of how it works this way, okay? On Santana, we looked at the timing of construction prices and we said, there is no question
componenttext: Let me do the Santana piece, in terms of what I was thinking there and let Dawn talk about the Avalon deals specifically in terms of how it works this way, okay? On Santana, we looked at the timing of construction prices and we said, there is no question that anytime anybody is living or staying even overnight at Santana in the form of either the hotel, the rental product that we have or the condos, that it carries such a premium because of what happens on the ground floor and even though, look, it's an awful tough time to be adding new product. If you sit and think about, it in the worst part of 2009 when we started, we said we know we can get the right construction costs to get this done, and we know that we're going to get that building filled up. And so we started and so as we got into this, we got more and more comfortable that yes, in fact, that was what was going to happen. There was real demand and look, we haven't leased one of those 109 units yet. It's under construction. So it's still just speculative. But it looks good enough to me, and we know we'll make money someday for sure on the condo. I'm converting it to condos, but it looks we're going to make some pretty good money just on the rentals, so much so that we kind of took the -- we've taken a hard look at the next piece of land, which we weren't going to do until we saw how this first project worked out behind, it's called Building A, one of the other buildings there. And so we'd like to get on it and jump on it now, and get started on it, which we are. So that positive outlook has everything to do with the specific location and feel of Santana and I was trying to -- I’ve been trying to allude to in my comments, Bethesda Row and Santana Row are two great examples of places where we really are seeing amazing traction these days. And part of it's maturity of the property. Part of it is maturity of the merchandising mix and some tweaking that we're doing there. But there's some momentum at that type of product. That's one of the things we like about the first couple of buildings certainly on Newbury, certainly what we like about Third Street Promenade. So very positive stuff that way. It's also impacting how we feel about Assembly, in terms of what Assembly could be down the road. And so maybe let me leave it at that and just ask your question about the ABB deal to Dawn.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, let me give you a little perspective on what we've got planned with Avalon so you understand in the context of the project. What we've talked to Avalon about is really they'll be coming in with us on the first phase of the development, which wo
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, let me give you a little perspective on what we've got planned with Avalon so you understand in the context of the project. What we've talked to Avalon about is really they'll be coming in with us on the first phase of the development, which would be three buildings to really get the project started with 400 residential units and about 225,000 square feet of retail to supplement the Assembly Square Mall, which has 300,000-plus square feet of retail just across the way from it. So it's the first starting point and what we have worked through with Avalon right now are really how we're going to build this project together. And much as you've seen before with us, Avalon's going to build the project, we buy back the retail. So we'll control the retail long term, Avalon will control the residential long term. I don't want to get into financial specifics of anything at this point, but that's the groundwork for it. And where we are at this point is everybody is working hard on the Avalon side on their due diligence to confirm where they are. And I think based on everything we've seen and the work they've done in advance, everyone's feeling very positive that from their perspective on the residential that we've got a good project going forward and we're seeing some really great interest from a lot of the retailers we're talking about, particularly entertainment venues as well as retail, as well as the restaurants out there. So that's all going to play out over the next several months, with hopefully the public funding coming together. So sometime I think as Don said towards the end of '11, we'd be able to have all the pieces really hitting their stride and get that first phase of development up and running to be the catalyst for the rest of the development out there.

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's actually on Assembly Square and maybe this is for you, Don and for Andy, I'm just trying to think, I guess maybe about NAV, if you will. Maybe you can give us some pieces because I think your gross investment there is about $190 million, but I'm assu
componenttext: It's actually on Assembly Square and maybe this is for you, Don and for Andy, I'm just trying to think, I guess maybe about NAV, if you will. Maybe you can give us some pieces because I think your gross investment there is about $190 million, but I'm assuming that exceeds sort of what I would assume is justified by the NOI that it throws off today. Are you able to share with us what the NOI is of Assembly Square, so maybe we can guesstimate how much investment you've made sort of in the future over the project, if you will that doesn't really cash flow today?

headline: Federal Realty Investment Trust, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I will give you a couple of points of where we were. When we bought the property, we spent $100 million on the existing mall and the completion of that existing mall and that threw off about around $7 million. And really from the beginning of this th
componenttext: Yes, I will give you a couple of points of where we were. When we bought the property, we spent $100 million on the existing mall and the completion of that existing mall and that threw off about around $7 million. And really from the beginning of this thing, I said well, okay so we're sitting there with a yielding landslide. It started at seven basically, which I viewed wonderfully in terms of starting with that and then having this other big piece of land behind it. Now we have a bunch more of that land to buy if we wanted to do something and we have done that over the years. But so we started 100 with the seven. We did knock down on the existing development site about $1.5 million worth of some pretty sloppy retail, but no offense to anybody that was there in the sloppy group, but some pretty sloppy retail a couple of years back. And so we've got remaining about $5.5 million or so of income. At the same time we've bought a lot of additional pieces of land and so you're absolutely right, $190 million certainly is not supported by $5.5 million of NOI, in terms of a value creation, value creative proposition, works for accounting not value creation. And so the idea of what we do going forward, how we do it in pieces, we're doing very much on a phase-by-phase justifiable basis, and this would be the first phase of development. In my view, second phase of Assembly Row.
